description: On January 23, 2020, the Coordination Office of Measures on Emerging Infectious Diseases, Cabinet Secretariat (Japan), established a website on "Countermeasures Against the Novel Coronavirus".
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 21, the Governor of Saitama stated that "For now, the best strategy to prevent the spread of the virus is for everyone to avoid infection. By keeping the concepts of 'I will not infect others' and 'I will not be infected by others' in mind, one can easily protect their family and loved ones."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In this context, it was agreed to “d) Take necessary measures for children who have temporarily returned from China, including supporting their acceptance and preventing bullying at schools.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In this context, it was agreed to “b) Call on consumers and businesses to remain calm and refrain from overstocking, to ensure there are enough masks and other goods necessary for the people.”

On March 12, the Hiroshima Prefecture issued a warning to warn against scams: "Counseling regarding fraudulent e-mails and phone calls using the "new coronavirus" is sent to the Consumer Affairs Counseling Service in the prefecture."
On March 27, Saga Prefecture Governor condemned "incidents where businesses refuse people's entries just because they're foreigners".

By joining the LINE official account "Okayama-Personal support for new corona countermeasures", the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) can inform its citizens about the new coronavirus according to their status, as announced on April 2.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) will “call for a calm response in order to prevent confusion including panic buying of food, medicine and daily necessities.”
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will work with the government in informing the residents that the emergency measures are different from "lockdown" (city blockade).”
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, it was agreed to “[i]nform the public that the government will not take measures such as "lockdown" (city blockade), and call for a calm response from the people (self-restraint of travel across prefectures, such as nonessential visits to hometowns and travel, avoiding flooding of shops and panic buying).”

In Fukuoka Prefecture (Japan) from April 8, "police warn people to be cautious" about "corona-linked fraud" and to "consult others when encountering such suspicious situations". For example, there had been cases of victims who "failed to receive surgical masks and other sanitation products they ordered online" and of "suspicious emails and phone calls offering corporate bonds" to develop corona cures.

On May 12, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) posted a warning against potential scams related to the coronavirus: "There have been some consultations such as suspicious e-mails and telephones masquerading as the payment procedure for special fixed benefit, which is suspected of being scammed by a new coronavirus infection."

On May 13, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) issued an announcement to its citizens that suspicious phone calls, emails and short messages (SMS), social networking services (SNS), websites, etc. regarding new coronavirus infectious diseases and special fixed benefit have been confirmed. "Please be careful of unfamiliar phone calls, e-mails, and websites so that you will not fall victim to crimes caused by these new coronavirus infections."
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 18. the Okayama Prefecture is asking all citizens of the prefecture to act from the standpoint of the other person based on the correct information announced by the national government and local governments. "In relation to the new coronavirus infection, slanderous slander against infected persons, their families, persons involved in medical institutions, persons in specific countries, and unsubstantiated and discriminatory writings on SNS etc. are seen. Such acts are human rights violations and are not permissible."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 22, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) issued a declaration prohibiting discrimination, prejudice, and slander against those infected by the coronavirus.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Justice,Municipal Government

description: In early August, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) initiated a campaign to create an advertisement that shows that infection risk can be eliminated by basic measures in buses, taxis, and trains, and we have begun posting them on the bodies of taxis, high-speed, chartered buses, etc.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 25, 2020, the draft “Ordinance on Cluster Measures for Preventing the Spread of New Coronavirus Infection in Tottori Prefecture” was approved after a revised decision at the extraordinary session in August 2 of the Tottori Prefectural Assembly (Japan). The ordinance prohibits slander and unfair discriminatory behavior regarding new-type coronavirus infections.

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed that “B) b) Prefectural governments, etc., shall request schools and other institutions to take appropriate measures including presentation of infection control policies at their facilities and temporary closures of schools.

description: On May 1, 2020, the Minister of Education, Science and Technology of Japan (MEXT) Hagiuda Koichi announced the release of "guidelines on how schools closed due to the coronavirus outbreak could resume classes in stages." "The guidelines propose staggered attendance by grade or class, with priority given to the first and final grades of elementary schools and seniors at junior high schools." The Ministry "also said that schools should divide children into groups by using unused classrooms and keep distances of one to 2 meters between seats. The notice proposed staggered class schedules by time and by day. It also said that physical education and other activities should not be conducted in congested environments."

On April 14, Fukui declares a state of emergency at the prefectural level. This SoE will be maintained until May 6.

The revised end date of SoE which announced on May 14 was May 31. However, since the new infection cases decreased radically, Fukui Prefecture Government decides to declare the end of SoE on May 26 when is 5 days earlier than the revised end of the date.

On April 14, Fukui declares a state of emergency at the prefectural level. This SoE will be maintained until May 6. However, on May 14, Fukui prefecture government extends its SoE from May 6 to May 31 due to the current surge of new infection cases in Japan.

On May 14, 2020, the Government of Japan "lifted the coronavirus state of emergency for 39 of the country's 47 prefectures." description: On April 13, Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) declared a state of warning against COVID-19. However, the national government of Japan declared a state of emergency on the country on April 16.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On April 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo declared that "the virus has been spreading in six prefectures — Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi, and Kyoto — to the same extent as in the seven prefectures where the state of emergency originally applied. Those seven are Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Hyogo and Fukuoka." Accordingly, the "13 prefectures have now been designated as "special alert prefectures" where it is necessary to promote efforts to prevent the spread of infections."
On April 16, 2020, Hokkaido Prefectural Government announced a state of emergency "to prevent the further spread of COVID-19" from April 17 to May 31.
On April 17, 2020, the town major of Taketomi (Ishigaki, Yaeyama Islands, Okinawa) Nishiōmasu Kōjun declared the island's own state of emergency in order to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus.

On May 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzo announced that the Government of Japan "intend[s] to request the Expert Meeting to assess the [emergency] situation" on May 14. The Government of Japan will "ask the Expert Meeting to conduct detailed analyses on the trend of new cases in each area and the degree of pressure on medical treatment structures."
The original end of the prefectural state of emergency was May 6, and it has been extended to May 31.

On May 6, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, announced that "[l]ifting state of emergency to be reviewed on a weekly basis." "Having extended its nationwide state of emergency by a month, the government now says it will consider week by week whether to lift it earlier and offered May 21 as a new date, depending on infection rates."
Following the national government on May 14, the Shimane Prefectural Government (Japan) has lifted the state of emergency and will relax restrictions.

description: At a press conference on June 23, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "it has been decided to operate special flights from Japan to Viet Nam over the three-day period on June 25, 26, and 27 arranged by the Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Viet Nam. Through these flights, it is planned for about 440 Japanese residents and businesspeople to travel to Viet Nam. They will be the first flights from Japan to Viet Nam since the agreement to relax restrictions partially and gradually on mutual travel between our countries. For this travel, the people who go to Viet Nam will enter the country in accordance with Viet Nam’s designated process of measures to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus. Also, among the travelers, businesspeople who will return to Japan after a relatively short time are expected to enter Japan in accordance with the trial measures for entry based on the decision made last week on June 18 by the National Security Council (NSC) and the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters. Specifically, on the condition that they comply with additional infection control measures, it is expected that measures will apply to them that enable limited business activities during the 14-day waiting period, such as waiting at home."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings

description: On August 4, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "for organizations mainly conducting elementary and secondary education, from the perspective of ensuring the right of children to receive education, we will allow new entry and re-entry to Japan by human resources that are difficult to find adequate replacements for within Japan, as they have “special circumstances” that make them exceptions to denial to enter Japan. From this perspective, coordination has been conducted with related ministries and agencies to allow re-entry by teachers at international schools and their families who have status of residence in Japan, as well as entry into Japan by newly-appointed teachers."
target_geog_level: All countries

description: From January 8, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture requests that residents who have symptoms such as coughing or fever after returning from Wuhan City should go to a medical institution.

On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided that "if it is confirmed that a person is infected at a medical institution, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases should  arrange proper inspection and retrace the close contacts of the infected person."

On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting decided to "implement national border control measures, such as checking the health status of people entering the country from areas with a high risk of infection, with tools such as thermographies at quarantine stations."

On January 28th, the Hokkaido Department of Health issued a statement regarding the health monitoring of travelers. After surveying 22 traveling participants, the Department confirmed that two displayed symptoms of COVID-19. All travelers who have tested positive are requested to implement anti-infection measures in the hospital, and all Hokkaido citizens are requested to monitor their health, particularly those who plan to travel or come into contact with travelers.

On January 28th, the Regional Health Division of Hokkaido asked citizens with suspected symptoms to "wear a mask and undergo a medical examination." Once having undergone examination, patients will be contacted with test results. Patients are asked to observe their health for 14 days, and in case of specified infections, are recommended to admit themselves to a hospital.

On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that "[t]aking into consideration the fact that individuals have tested positive for the virus despite exhibiting no symptoms, it is necessary for us to phase up our responses including quarantine measures. [...] We will introduce a measure, aimed at all people entering Japan with any history of travelling to Wuhan or related areas, that checks their contact information while in Japan and follows up on their health status, regardless of whether or not they have exhibited any symptoms."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 7, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture establishes a Returnee and Contact Consultation Center at 19 health centers in the prefecture to provide COVID-19 advice for returnees from overseas and their contacts.
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time

description: On February 7, 2020 in Tokyo, Japan, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government in conjunction with the special wards of Tokyo Metropolis, Hachioji City, and Machida City established a call center for Tokyo Metropolis residents with fevers or respiratory symptoms and/or those who have returned from abroad or had contact with returning residents.  Inquirers to this hotline may be referred for medical examination if they meet certain criteria.

Fukuoka Prefecture advises from February 20, 2020 that residents with "cold symptoms or high fever" (37.5 degrees Celsius or more) and/or continual "excessive fatigue or difficulty with breathing" for more than four days should phone a medical center for consultation. On the other hand, "elderly people and others who have underlying diseases" should phone if these symptoms continue for more than two days.
link: NA ; https://www.pref.fukuoka.lg.jp/uploaded/attachment/62642.pdf ; Fukuoka Prefecture ; Things to watch out for in your daily life if you think you have COVID (in Japanese)

description: On February 20, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture announces that all people with COVID-19 symptoms should go to a consultation center, rather than just people who travelled to Wuhan and have symptoms.

On February 21, the Governor of Saitama Prefecture announced that "Those who have cold-like symptoms and/or a fever (37.5°C and bove) that persists for more than four consecutive days, please do not hesitate to seek consultation. In particular, the elderly, those who suffer from chronic illnesses, those who are pregnant, and those who feel severely fatigued or have difficulty breathing are recommended to seek consultation as soon as possible. If you suspect infection, please refer to the 'Consultation Centers for Persons Returning to Japan or Those Who May Have Been in Contact with New Coronavirus.'"

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed to “A) b) Encourage people to contact the Call Center for Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts, which refer suspected patients to outpatient facilities from the viewpoint of accurately grasping the situations of outbreak and preventing the further spread, as seeking medical care without consulting due to the anxiety from potential infection may lead to increased risk of infection.”

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to “(2) understan[d] the situation of infection in Japan,” it was agreed to “B) Establish the surveillance system to grasp the epidemic situation in Japan, while switching to use of PCR test for the confirmation of diagnosis necessary to treat pneumonia patients who require hospitalization, in communities where the number of patients continues to increase."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed that “B) a) The elderly and those with underlying diseases are encouraged to seek appropriate medical care at the early stage, given their vulnerability to the infection.”

Saga Prefecture set up a 24/7 phone line from March 1 "exclusively for foreign residents to help them speak to the consultation centers in 18 languages" regarding coronavirus symptoms. The provided languages are English, Chinese, Korean, Vietnamese, Malay, Nepalese, Tagalog, Bahasa Indonesian, Portuguese, French, Spanish, Russian, Italian, German, Thai, Burmese, Khmer and Mongolian.

Kagoshima Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Disease Control Headquarters requests from March 27 for residents to call the Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts advice line in the event of a long term fever, symptoms of tiredness, suffocating or difficulty in breathing.

On March 30, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced the promotion of health monitoring measures on its village ferries. Body temperature and health conditions of crew members will be checked every day. Before boarding the ferry, the temperature of passengers will be taken. These measures will be effective from April 1, 2020.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect.”

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, prefectural governments “will provide guidance to school operators on infectious disease countermeasures such as health management.”

On April 7, 2020, the Welfare Department of Tarama Island and Tarama Clinic asked residents to contact the clinic "if you have been out of Okinawa or outside the prefecture or if your relatives have been visiting you from Okinawa main island or from outside Okinawa prefecture after March 20." "Regarding homecoming high school children due to the prefectural extension of public high school closure, please measure the temperature twice daily and monitor cough, runny nose, sore throat." [loose translation from Japanese]
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "7) Strengthening counter-cluster measures" it was decided that "i) Active epidemiological investigations will be organized to identify individuals who have been in close contact with infected persons, monitor their health conditions, request them to refrain from leaving home, and properly grasp the scale of the spread of infections for appropriate infection control."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4 2020 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding the Maintenance and Relaxation, etc of State of Emergency Measures”. With regards to (3) matters shared by Prefectures under Special Caution and designated prefectures other than the Prefectures under Special Caution as part of 3) restrictions on the use of facilities it was decided that, concerning infection prevention, prefectures will adopt contact tracing app and SNS technology and inform people that these technologies will allow the infection situation regarding the users of facilities to be grasped.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Included in the document is consideration that “i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms” and the decision was made to “Use information communication devices to monitor the health status of those who recover at home for reasons such as childcare.”

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). To continue “(2) Surveillance and information gathering efforts,” the MHLW will “Develop a system for sharing information about patients, etc. as soon as possible; [and] Use the system to gather and analyze statistical data for more effective and efficient measures.”

With regards to “8) Strengthening counter-cluster measures” it has been decided that “i) Active epidemiological investigations will be organized to identify individuals who have been in close contact with infected persons, monitor their health conditions, request them to refrain from leaving home, and properly grasp the scale of the spread of infections for appropriate infection control.”

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). With regards to “8) Strengthening counter-cluster measures,” the MHLW has decided to “iii) Create more effective counter-cluster measures, while gaining an understanding of the people with regards to apps for confirming contacts developed by smartphone developers, and also while paying close attention to personal information protection and privacy.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: As of May 22, the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) is mandating its citizens to contact a consultation center if any of their symptoms continue for four days or longer. "If you feel that your symptoms are strong, please consult immediately, as the symptoms vary with the individual. This also applies to those who are taking antipyretics.) We ask that individuals with symptoms take leave from work or school and refrain from going out."

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to guarantee the (2) Surveillance and Information gathering, it was agreed to “[b]uild a framework for effective surveillance, such as surveys on antibody prevalence.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Japan (Tokyo), on June 05, 2020, "in order to safely use the metropolitan facilities visited by many users, [the Tokyo Metropolitan Government] build a new 'Tokyo version of new corona watching service' from the viewpoint of preventing the spread of new coronavirus infection".
"This service is a mechanism that promptly notifies the user of infection information based on the visit history of the facility when a new coronavirus infectious disease cluster occurs in a metropolitan facility."
Targeted facilities include Metropolitan cultural facilities, sports facilities, gardens/zoos, libraries, etc. (will be expanded in the future).

On June 19, 2020, the Government of Japan has begun "offering a smartphone app that alerts users of close contact with people infected with the novel coronavirus. The Cocoa app is aimed at preventing the spread of the virus by urging users with infection risks to get tested as soon as possible. [...] When users who have installed the app on their smartphones are located within a meter of each other for 15 minutes or more, their devices will exchange information of the encounter via the Bluetooth wireless technology and record it for 14 days. When a user is confirmed to be infected with the coronavirus, the local public health center will issue a code that the user can enter on the app. A server will gather information on the individual's encounters with other users, and notify them via the app that they had been in close contact with the infected patient."

On June 19, the Saga prefecture (Japan) announced that it will be using the mew coronavirus contact confirmation application (COCOA), developed to contribute to extended prevention of new coronavirus infectious disease in Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 23, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has "temporarily stop[ep] the app from issuing any alerts," as it "erroneously accepts reference numbers not issued by the Health, Labor and Welfare Ministry." "To prevent confusion, officials have halted the issuance of personal numbers. This means the app's contact-notification function will remain out of service. Officials say they plan to fix the flaw as soon as possible."

Japan, on June 26, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced, it will implement the "'Store-type Tokyo version of New Corona Monitoring Service', an infection information notification service regarding cluster outbreaks of new-type coronavirus infectious diseases based on the history of visits to private stores by users", in cooperation with several Corona Tech partner companies (Event Resist Co., Ltd., Yahoo Japan Corporation, Ikkyu Co., Ltd.). The business will start on June 27, 2020.
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 3, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has "resumed its coronavirus contact-tracing app service." "The ministry says users need to update their app to the latest version."
From July 15, Fukuoka Prefecture encourages residents to use COCOA, "a contract-tracing application developed to prevent the spread" of COVID-19.

On July 22, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) established a branch office of the Traveler’s Access Center Okinawa (TACO) at Miyako Airport. The office will provide health consultations for visitors. If fever is confirmed, it will be possible, with the consent of the patient, to transfer with a dedicated car from the airport to Miyako Hospital in order to conduct a PCR test.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On July 24, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) urges its citizens to visit the consultation center if they had visited the Koyama Chinese Cuisine in an effort to conduct contact tracing with novel coronavirus cases.

July 28 2020, Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (2) the adoption of contact tracing apps, etc within 2) Efforts to encourage restaurant users adopt behaviour to protect themselves it was decided that people will be encouraged to download the COCOA contact tracing app and register to use local governments’ own notification systems.
type_sub_cat: Who a person has come into contact with over time
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: As announced on July 31, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) will utilize more digital technologies to more efficiently detect and track cases.

On August 3, the Tottori Municipal Public Health Center (Japan) announced the planned implementation of the examination for the faculty members of Tottori City Higashi Junior High School and all the school students in relation to the 15th case positive in the prefecture (12th case of the Tottori City Public Health Center).
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On August 5, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) launched a coronavirus countermeasure security system. 

"If a person who is positive for the new coronavirus is found among the participants of a large-scale event held in Tottori Prefecture, a service will be sent from the prefecture to alert the recipients to the email address registered at the venue."

On August 12, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that it "plans to ask elderly facilities to simulate a coronavirus outbreak by the end of August, as part of its resurgence response." "Staff at the facilities will also be asked to check stock levels of sanitary goods such as disinfectant and face masks and how they are checking the health of the staff. With the steps, the ministry aims to prevent an infection cluster among elderly people with a higher risk of developing serious conditions." "Facilities will have to report to the ministry by early September on whether they have taken the steps. Facilities required to carry out such simulations are special elderly nursing homes, nursing care facilities, homes for the elderly with care services and other establishments where many old people live together."

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked schools to "continue to make every effort to prevent infections" and families to "cooperate in observing the health of their children."

As of August 14, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) will begin using its new "Hiroshima Corona News QR" service that uses QR codes to inform citizens that they may have contacted an infected person and supports them to have a PCR test to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infections.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government “implement[s] regular screening all at once for all those who work at medical institutions and care facilities for the elderly so as to prevent group infections among people at high risk of developing severe symptoms.”

On October 16, 2020, it was reported that the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) "has been repeatedly urging the Bangladesh government to take adequate measures to protect all personnel engaged in the 84 Japanese-funded development projects around the country from Covid-19. It also wants the government to provide medical care to those who have been already infected. The organisation has written to the government's Economic Relations Division (ERD) three times so far on this issue."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan agreed "to set up a hub serving as a public health center and a fever clinic for outpatients. The council[, composed by the central government, the Tokyo metropolitan government and the organizing committee of the Tokyo Games,] will start work on details, including securing staff personnel for the new bases." "The hub serving as a public health center is likely to be established in or near the athlete village, which will be used by up to some 30,000 people. If athletes or other people linked to the Tokyo Games are confirmed with the virus, the hub will conduct active epidemiological surveys in coordination with the infectious disease center and identify those who had close contact with the infected individuals."
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan agreed "to establish an infectious disease response center to monitor the health conditions of athletes participating in the Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games in the summer of 2021. The agreement was struck at a meeting of a coordination council over the novel coronavirus epidemic among the central government, the Tokyo metropolitan government and the organizing committee of the Tokyo Games." "The infectious disease response center, to be set up as part of the organizing committee, will check the health of Olympians and Paralympians throughout the sporting events. If athletes test positive for the novel coronavirus, the center will share necessary information with their national delegations and related sports organizations."
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 29 January 2020, Osaka Prefecture, Japan, established a telephone consultation service for citizens of the prefecture. The consultation service is available everyday, including weekends and public holidays from 9:00AM to 6:00PM.

On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, on May 29, 2020, Hokkaido prefecture establishes a system to test for new coronaviruses at the Hokkaido Prefectural Institute of Public Health.
Japan, on May 29, 2020, Hokkaido prefecture establishes a system to test for new coronaviruses at the Hokkaido Prefectural Institute of Public Health.

On January 31, 2020, the Ministry of Defence of Japan (MOD) "issued an order to send SDF personnel to deal with mass infections at the Diamond Princess cruise ship quarantined off the coast of Japan. This mission was completed on March 16." The Self-Defence Force (SDF) carried out disaster relief activities and livelihood support. The vessel "Hakuo" will be used as a base for SDF personnel.

On February 1, 2020, at the Fourth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "[e]ven for those individuals who have tested negative, [the Government is] thoroughly monitoring health condition of each and every person under appropriate controls, by stationing doctors at all accommodation facilities on a round-the-clock basis, [and] also providing push-mode support for daily living essentials, including face masks, sanitizers, thermometers, and other daily items, to those privately-owned accommodations and government facilities who have pledged their cooperation."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus.

On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. 

From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre will be extended. On weekdays, the Centre will be open between 08:30 and 21:00. The weekend hours will remain the same as before, from 10:00 to 16:00.

description: "The Government of Japan decided to provide China with 4,800 safety goggles and 5,200 isolation suits, which are part of the equipment stockpiled by Asia-Europe Foundation (ASEF) and financed by Japan’s contribution, as in-kind contribution from the Government of Japan. This in-kind contribution was transported to Wuhan by the chartered flight which left Japan on Wednesday, February 6, and handed over to the Chinese side at Wuhan Tianhe International Airport on Thursday, February 7."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: From February 7, 2020 to February 12, 2020 in Tokyo, Japan, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Bureau of Social Welfare and Public Health supplied 20,000 sets of protective clothing to medical institutions and healthcare centers in Tokyo.

On February 6, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) instituted a new "telephone consultation service" for the new coronavirus. The new consultation desk will be reachable free of charge from 9am to 9pm at the number 0120-565653, starting from February 7, 2020.

Since February 10, 2020, "Yokohama [(Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan)] has set up a call center to handle inquiries about the coronavirus." "The move comes after it received more 1,100 phone calls directed to public health care centers around the city since Jan. 16. The call center is open from 9 a.m.-9 p.m., seven days a week, including holidays."

description: On February 13, 2020, at the Eight Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that the Government "will extend supports to secure over 1,800 beds among medical institutions across Japan that are capable of accommodating patients."

description: On February 16, 2020, at the Tenth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "the Government will more closely collaborate with local governments and implement various measures, including [...] increasing of the number of medical institutions with enhanced medical treatment systems in place from the current 726 to 800."

description: On February 16, 2020, at the Tenth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that "the Government will more closely collaborate with local governments and implement various measures, including [...] a 24-hour response, including Saturdays and Sundays, by the 536 consultation centers which were established in each and every prefecture."

description:
On February 17, the Tottori prefecture (Japan) issued a statement, urging its citizens to contact a "Coronavirus Consultation Center if they have any of the below symptoms:
(1) Cold symptoms and/or a fever above 37.5 degrees Celsius which lasts for 4 days or more (2 days or more for the elderly or those with preexisting health problems.)
(2) Heavy physical fatigue or trouble breathing"
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: At the end of February 2020, Japan National Tourism Organization (JNTO) "published a webpage titled, "For Safe Travels in Japan: Guide for when you are feeling ill," which allows users to find medical professionals in their area that speak English, Chinese, and Korean, plus other languages (Polish, French, German) that are less available. It also includes a brief guide for how to use travel medical insurance and typical Japanese hospital procedures. The tourism site also launched the Bebot x JNTO chatbot, which gives users information on COVID-19, restrictions on travel from China, travel insurance, as well as the option to "speak to human.""
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 21, it was announced that "Saitama Prefecture has preceded other prefectures and even the country in setting up a 24-hour consultation center."

On February 27, 2020, it was reported that the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) "had decided to provide primer and testing reagents (equivalent to 400,000 yen in total) which is used to test for the rapid detection of the new coronavirus" "as a countermeasure against the new coronavirus (COVID-19) in Myanmar, responding to an urgent request from the National Health Laboratory (NHL)" of Myanmar.

(Local communities should discuss and consider in advance the medical institutions that do not accept the suspected cases of the novel coronavirus infection (i.e.: dialysis and obstetric medical institutions, etc.)).”

On February 25, 2020, at the 13th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stated that "[i]n response to the request from the Governor of Hokkaido yesterday, we will today dispatch a response team to Hokkaido."

description:
On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre will be extended. On weekdays, the Centre will be open between 08:30 and 21:00. The weekend hours will remain the same as before, from 10:00 to 16:00.

From 1 May onwards the opening hours will be adjusted again. The new opening hours are: Monday to Saturday open 24 hours and closed on Sunday. The fax contact number will also be changed.
link: NA ; http://www.pref.nara.jp/item/227615.htm#moduleid36467ara Prefecture ; About telephone consultation counter for citizens of the new coronavirus infectious disease ; http://www.pref.nara.jp/secure/227615/200430hodo.pdf

description: On February 26, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture "has established a help desk for COVID-19 as well as the countermeasures for virus infection." Okinawa Prefecture "has set up a round-the-clock hotline serviced by medical professionals who provide information on medical institutions that can handle foreign languages. The service is available in English, Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, Portuguese, Spanish, Vietnamese and Thai."

According to the Ministry of Justice of Japan (MOJ), inmates of "seven prisons in Aomori, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo, Yamaguchi and Kochi prefecture" have been sewing "cloth face masks" since March 2020. "Having received orders from private-sector companies, these prisons now have the combined capacity to sew some 66,000 such masks a month. They also started preparations to make medical gowns that are in short supply as well."

description: In Sendai, to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, BCG vaccination in March is, as a general rule, carried out only for children who are one year old by the beginning of April and have not been vaccinated. If the vaccination period can be delayed, please inoculate after April. For children who are currently eligible for vaccination, parents will be notified individually.

On March 2, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture requests that medical institutions prepare a COVID-19 patient acceptance system. This system is needed in the event that patient numbers increase in the prefecture and there are insufficient beds to treat them in the designated infectious disease medical institutions.

Hiratsuka City(Kanagawa, Japan) government distributed a total of about 25,000 masks to all 158 facilities including kindergartens, nursery schools, and after-school children's clubs in the city on March 3rd, 2020.

"Japanese Defense Minister Taro Kono issued on Saturday [(March 28, 2020)] an order to dispatch Self-Defense Forces troops as part of his country's efforts to strengthen quarantine steps amid the spread of the new coronavirus. From Saturday, the dispatched troops are engaged in the work to quarantine people arriving at Tokyo International Airport at Haneda and Narita International Airport in Chiba Prefecture, east of Tokyo. They are also supporting the transport of such people to designated facilities. The Defense Ministry dispatched SDF members on a voluntary basis based on a judgment that the current situation represents a case stipulated by the SDF law where the ministry should not wait for a dispatch request from a prefectural governor."

Fukuoka Prefecture announces that while other businesses will close, medical facilities such as hospitals and clinics will remain open between April 14 and May 6, 2020.

On April 14, 2020, Osaka Prefecture "began to treat mildly ill or asymptomatic patients of the novel coronavirus at a business hotel in the city of Osaka [...] in an effort to prevent the local medical system from collapsing amid the crisis. The prefectural government has set aside funds for 3,000 rooms for such people." Moreover, "13 hospitalized people moved to Super Hotel Osaka Natural Hot Springs. [...] Nurses will be at the hotel for full-time services to check patients' conditions every day and respond to any sudden changes in their conditions. At the hotel, 400 rooms are secured for coronavirus patients."

On April 14, 2020 the Osaka City Mayor Ichiro Matsui designated Osaka City Jūsō Hospital as a specialised COVID-19 hospital. Existing patients with illnesses other than COVID-19 will be transferred to other hospitals and vacant wards will gradually accept COVID-19 patients who are not seriously ill, but are experiencing mild symptoms that require hospital care and equipment such as “oxygen inhalation.” Once all of the transfers and preparations are completed, the hospital will re-open as a specialised COVID-19 hospital although the date is not yet fixed. 

On May 1, 2020 Osaka City announced that it had completed the transfer and discharge of patients at Osaka City Jūsō Hospital. 

Following the transfer of all patients, on May 22, 2020, the Osaka City Jūsō Hospital began operating as a specialised COVID-19 hospital in preparation for the “second wave” of COVID-19 cases.

description: On 16 April 2020, the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare updated their mental health portal “Kokoronomimi” and created a new page addressing COVID-19 and emotional care. The page was added due to the recognition that people may be experiencing anxiety and stress at work or in their personal lives due to COVID-19. The page will host information on COVID-19  and consultation services through SNS (LINE, Twitter, Facebook), email and telephone.
As announced on April 17 in the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) by the governor, the prefecture is securing around 700 beds and will increase PCR tests.

description: On 04-08-2020, Okinawa, Japan authorities began discussions with the prefectural hotel association and prefectural hotel sanitation workers' union about the possibility of using hotels to lodge mildly infected COVID-19 patients. On 04-17-2020, Okinawa announced that this policy would begin with the 'Toyoko INN Naha Asahibashi Station' in Naha, Okinawa.
Japan, on Apr. 14 Yamagata government announces a donation of95 masks to child-related facilities on Apr. 17.

description: The Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi announced on April 19, 2020 that the Government of Japan "has secured over 210,000 hotel rooms nationwide to accommodate those with mild coronavirus symptoms as well as asymptomatic patients as the country tries to contain the spread of the virus."

description: The National Tax Agency of Japan announced on April 21, 2020, "that it will temporarily allow the sale of sake brewers' alcohol as disinfectant liquid, which is running short amid the novel coronavirus outbreak." "The agency will also promote the use of hard spirits and liquors made by adding fruits and herbs to redistilled "shochu" spirits as disinfectants. To this end, it will promptly issue a limited license to many shochu distillers across the country."

Japan, „The Fukui Prefectural Government said Sunday |Apr.19) it will distribute coupons granting the right to purchase face masks to all households in the prefecture“, sell will be from Apr. 24th until May10th.
The prefectural government will send the coupons by mail from Thursday [Apr.23th]. All households in the prefecture, totaling about 290,000, are expected to receive the coupon by the end of April.

description: On April 24, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "[m]ore day care and short-stay facilities for the elderly have shut as the government expanded the state of emergency over the coronavirus crisis nationwide April 16." "The ministry is asking providers of the services to try to keep their facilities open as much as possible."
Kagoshima Prefecture announced on 24 April that three accommodation facilities have been secured to treat patients with mild cases of COVID-19.

On April 24, 2020, at the 31st Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that Japan will "deliver 15 million [surgical masks throughout the country] within this month. Regarding medical gowns and other equipment, [Japan has] started delivery to prefectures, especially those with a significant number of patients. [The Government] also intend[s] to distribute 1.5 million high performance masks, such as N95 masks, 1.3 million medical gowns, and 1.9 million face shields nationwide, delivering them expeditiously to medical institutions facing shortages of such supplies."

On April 24, 2020, at the 31st Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that Japan will "deliver 15 million [surgical masks throughout the country] within this month. Regarding medical gowns and other equipment, [Japan has] started delivery to prefectures, especially those with a significant number of patients. [The Government] also intend[s] to distribute 1.5 million high performance masks, such as N95 masks, 1.3 million medical gowns, and 1.9 million face shields nationwide, delivering them expeditiously to medical institutions facing shortages of such supplies."

When a person who is insured by Tottori City National Health Insurance (Japan) is infected with a new coronavirus infection or has a fever etc, the Tottori Prefecture will pay the allowance. Registration began on April 27.

On April 27, 2020, it was announced that a "group of forensic pathologists in Japan says cases have occurred in which bodies of the deceased have been returned to families without undergoing coronavirus tests, despite experts' requests to carry out such checks." "To resolve the problem, forensic researchers in several universities have decided to carry out their own coronavirus tests."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: In Tottori prefecture, a new nursing center in Kurayoshi, a nursing center in central Japan, will open on April 27th .
In Tottori prefecture, a new nursing center in Kurayoshi, a nursing center in central Japan, will open on April 27th .

At a news conference on April 28, 2020, the Minister of Foreign Affairs of Japan MOTEGI Toshimitsu announced that "Japan will begin providing the anti-flu drug Avigan for free to 38 countries as early as this week for treating patients with the new coronavirus." The Minister added that "over 70 countries, including the 38, have made requests for Avigan to Japan, which has decided to offer a $1 million grant to the United Nations Office for Project Services to buy and distribute the drug, also known as favipiravir, to countries that want it."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: At the beginning of May 2020, the Cabinet Office of Japan told Japanese local governments "to make preparations to prevent the spread of the coronavirus at evacuation centers if natural disasters occur, ahead of the rainy and typhoon seasons." The Cabinet Office prompted "the local governments to set up as many evacuation centers as possible in the event of disasters and consider in advance how to cope with infected evacuees."

On 5 February 2020, Nara Prefecture established a Returnee/Contact Person Telephone Consultation Centre for those who suspect that they have been infected with the new COVID-19 virus. From 25 February 2020, the opening hours of the Centre were extended (weekdays between 08:30 and 21:00, weekend hours from 10:00 to 16:00). 
   
From 1 May onwards the opening hours will be adjusted again. From Monday to Saturday, the Centre will be open for 24 hours and then the Centre will be closed on Sunday. The fax contact number will also be changed.

On May 1, 2020 the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) updated the COVID-19 specific page on its mental health portal “Kokoronomimi” and added “Advice from an Expert.” In this column, an expert encourages thinking about the roots of everyday anxieties and worries as various aspects of one’s life are impacted by COVID-19.

On May 1, 2020, Osaka Prefecture Governor Hirofumi Yoshimura announced that the private hospital Hanwa Daini Hospital will be assigned as a specialised COVID-19 hospital, making it the second hospital in Osaka Prefecture designated specifically to accept COVID-19 patients. The Hanwa Daini Hospital will accept elderly persons who are considered at high risk of becoming severely ill due to COVID-19.
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "i) A hospital treatment system will be secured that focuses on providing medical care to those with severe symptoms" it was decided that “A system will be set up to coordinate the acceptance and transfer of patients. Medical institutions' information-gathering systems will be utilized so that the institutions can visualize information necessary for coordinating patient acceptance."

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). With regards to "v) Securing the supply of medical goods" it was decided that "A secure manufacturing system will be set up for medical supplies, medical equipment, and medical materials to provide them promptly and smoothly to medical institutions that need them." It specified that "In particular, the securing of supplies of personal protective equipment, such as masks for medical institutions that conduct PCR tests and admit patients, will be prioritized."

description: On May 5, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) announced that "Foreign Ministry's "Tabi-Regi" email-based security information service for Japanese travelers overseas will become available for users of the Line free messaging app. By improving user convenience, the ministry hopes to encourage people making foreign trips to register for the service, ministry officials said. The ministry aims to start the service for Line users in early 2021 at the earliest after a system upgrade."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) “approved remdesivir as the first treatment for COVID-19 in Japan, three days after the Japanese subsidiary of U.S.-based Gilead Sciences Inc. submitted the application. The process was accelerated under a special exception clause for pharmaceuticals that are approved by another nation with comparable standards as Japan’s.” “The health ministry will initially manage the supply and distribute remdesivir to hospitals with patients with severe symptoms. The drug will be provided for free at first.”

On May 9, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government (Japan) has "released a stockpile of data on the number of coronavirus tests conducted and the infection rate dating back to late January. Disjointed data on testing, not just in Tokyo but throughout Japan, has been the subject of controversy and scrutiny for months. Researchers say it’s impossible to understand the true severity of the pandemic without this information."

On May 9, 2020, it was announced that a "group of researchers at the University of Tokyo has started clinical trials of [...] [n]afamostat mesylate, [...] marketed under the brand name Futhan. The tests are being conducted on 160 patients with pneumonia stemming from the coronavirus at the University of Tokyo Hospital and five other medical facilities in Japan. The patients are divided into two groups. One group is administered Futhan and anti-flu drug Avigan. The other is given only Avigan. University of Tokyo Professor Inoue Junichiro is involved in the trials."
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On April 30, 2020 the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare announced that from May 11, 2020 the Health Center Real-time Information-sharing System on COVID-19 (HER-SYS) will be implemented in some public health centres. Following, the preliminary implementation, the system will be introduced country-wide on May 17, 2020

With this new digital system, doctors, hospitals and local public health centres can promptly share information on patients infected with covid-19 with relevant prefectural and national government departments. This will allow for smoother organisation of counter-cluster measures and the coordination of hospitalisations. Infected patients can also easily report changes in their health condition with the HER-SYS and can monitor their condition.

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). With regards to ‘ii) [Securing] an outpatient and testing system … for suspected COVID-19 patients’, this system would ‘Provide outpatient services to suspected COVID-19 patients under proper infection control by having them access Outpatient Services for Returnees and Contact Persons via the Call Centers for Japanese Returnees and Potential Contacts.’

description:
Due to the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, it is becoming difficult to obtain masks at stores. The Tottori prefecture (Japan), in cooperation with supermarkets etc., will arrange the purchase.
Mask purchase tickets will be distributed to all units in the prefecture between May 14th, 2020 (May 13th at some post offices) and 20th.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 18 May 2020, Nara Prefecture requested business operators and citizens of the prefecture to donate medical supplies. Requested medical supplies include medical gowns (surgical gowns and isolation gowns), plastic raincoats, masks (surgical, N95, non-textile masks). Those who have other medical equipment should first call the Nara Coronavirus Material Procurement and Distribution Group.

From June 2019, the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) has established a “ONE STOP” type of consultation desk in Shimane International Center to respond to various information and consultation regarding to the daily lives of foreign residents. Consultation is free. Since the outbreak in February 2020, the consultation has expanded to specialize in COVID-19 services.

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) "started a measure for supporting seven R&D projects [...] which are highly urgent and that must be tackled quickly, as part of the efforts undertaken in the Project for Developing Technologies for Addressing the Novel Coronavirus Disease and Other Infectious Diseases under the FY2020 Supplementary Budget established on April 30, 2020." One of the R&D projects, represented by the Nihon Kohden Corporation, pertains to the "feasibility verification of a remote control system targeting infected patients with mild COVID-19 symptoms and other patients, and research aimed at optimizing the system, as efforts toward reducing the risks of infection for medical workers."

description: On May 22, 2020, the Osaka City Jūsō Hospital began operating as a specialised COVID-19 hospital in preparation for the “second wave” of COVID-19 cases. Existing patients were transferred to different hospitals to prepare for the acceptance of COVID-19 patients who require hospitalisation, but experience mild symptoms that require hospital care and equipment such as “oxygen inhalation.” Increased hygiene measures were also implemented, such as covering carpet with an antibacterial vinyl sheet to make it easier to wipe.
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 22, 2020, it was announced that the Government of Japan "will support nine domestic studies aimed at developing a coronavirus vaccine with subsidies totaling 7.2 billion yen, or about 67 million dollars." "The funds are designed to support basic research and segments of clinical trials for an experimental vaccine. The nine projects were selected by the Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development. Four are led by companies; another four involve universities; and one, a research institute."

On May 22, 2020, the Osaka City Jūsō Hospital began operating as a specialised COVID-19 hospital in preparation for the “second wave” of COVID-19 cases. Existing patients were transferred to different hospitals to prepare for the acceptance of COVID-19 patients who require hospitalisation, but experience mild symptoms that require hospital care and equipment such as “oxygen inhalation.” Increased hygiene measures were also implemented, such as covering carpet with an antibacterial vinyl sheet to make it easier to wipe. 

On July 27, 2020, Osaka City Jūsō Hospital resumed outpatient treatment. All medical treatments and procedures will resume, excluding obstetrics.
enforcer: Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

In order to guarantee the (2) Surveillance and Information gathering, it was agreed to “[s]trengthen the testing system by utilizing local and private institutes; [i]ntroduce new testing technology promptly in the medical field; [p]romote the utilization of private testing institutes; [g]rasp the PCR testing system and make necessary coordination.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: The Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan)  submitted an additional supplementary budget of approximately 2.4 billion yen as the third step of emergency additional support for new coronavirus infectious diseases. This will increase the number of PCR tests to 440 cases and secure more empty beds for hospitalization.

The Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan)  submitted an additional supplementary budget of approximately 2.4 billion yen as the third step of emergency additional support for new coronavirus infectious diseases. This will increase the number of PCR tests to 440 cases and secure more empty beds for hospitalization.

On May 22, 2020, the Government of Japan "adopted an ordinance revision [...] to ban the resale of sanitizers and products that can be used as an alternative to disinfectants at prices higher than the acquisition costs." "The revised ordinance, which will come into force on Tuesday, will cover the resale of pharmaceutical and quasi-pharmaceutical products, such as sanitizers and alcohol-based hand soap products, and sanitizing products with an alcohol concentration of 60 pct or higher. Products without alcohol or not designed for disinfection will not be covered. Consumable alcohol of high concentrations will not be restricted either if it is resold for consumption."

If a person enrolled in the National Health Insurance System is infected with the new coronavirus (including cases where there is a symptom such as fever and infection is suspected), he/she will be able to pay the injury/illness allowance for the period during which he/she cannot receive labor for medical treatment, as announced by the Okayama prefecture (Japan) on May 27.

description: On June 4, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Abe Shinzō said that "Japan will provide about $300 million to a global organization dedicated to increasing access to vaccinations in developing countries. The financial support to Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, will be extended for five years from 2021 to make contributions to global public health efforts. [...] The Japanese government provided around $95 million to Gavi for the previous five-year period from 2016 to 2020. The upcoming donation of $300 million, including $100 million already pledged in April, is the largest amount Japan has provided to the nongovernmental body to date."
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On June 5, 2020, it was announced that the Government of Japan and the Deputy Minister for Investment and Foreign Economic Relations of Myanmar agreed on a "grant aid worth 2 billion Japanese Yen (approximately 18.1 million USD) for the provision of medical equipment in response to COVID-19." "This Grant Aid project provides medical equipment worth 2 billion Japanese yen (approximately 18.1 million USD) in total, such as radiography system, intensive care unit beds and medical monitors, to hospitals and laboratories in Myanmar." "The first flight carrying medical equipment [...] arrived at Yangon International Airport on 15 August 2020."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "opened a website where users pick the type of problem they are facing over the novel coronavirus to look for support measures that match their needs." "The website also has a mental health test function." "Smartphone users found to be stressed out can directly seek advice using the Line free messaging app."

On June 12, the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) announced the creation of the “Consultation Centers for Returning Travelers and
Persons in Contact” and “Outpatient Clinics for Returning Travelers and
Persons in Contact”, available at each healthcare center in Shimane. 
"These centers provide consultation to people suspected of
having COVID-19; they also help people to receive a medical exam at an “Outpatient Clinic for
Returning Travelers and Persons in Contact”"
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On June 18, 2020 the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) updated the COVID-19 specific page on its mental health portal “Kokoronomimi” and added “Advice from an Expert.” In this column, an expert reassures those who have gained weight from increased consumption of sweet foods during a time when self-restraint had to be exercised in many other aspects of life. The expert also encourages people to search for other sources of enjoyment as social activities resume.

On June 26, 2020, it was reported that the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) "has provide additional capacity development support to Ministry of Health (MoH)" of Uganda "under the on-going JICA’s technical cooperation." "JICA has been supporting quality improvement of infrastructure management and health care service delivery in Regional Referral Hospitals with regard to infectious diseases through the “5S-CQI-TQM” project." "JICA's donations to Uganda "included KN95 masks, surgical masks, surgical gloves, disposable gloves, gum boots, PPE’s full kits (coverall, head cover and goggles), pedal bins, and bin liners."

description: On July 6, 2020, "the Pacific governments, together with partners including UNICEF and the Governments of the United States, New Zealand and Japan, launched the "Health Care on Air Pacific training" to be aired on radio and other communication platforms for front-line healthcare workers across 14 countries: Fiji, Cook Islands, Samoa, Federated States of Micronesia, Palau, Tuvalu, Niue, Vanuatu, Solomon Islands, Kiribati, Nauru, Tonga, Republic of Marshall Islands and Tokelau."

description:
As published on July 8, the Okayama Prefecture (Japan) has suspended group examinations due to worries about the spread of the coronavirus, switching instead to individual medical checkups of infants and toddlers. Checkpoints will proceed until the end of July. 

"The shift is aimed at preparing health care workers and the wider medical system for an expected second wave of COVID-19 infections."

On June 15, 2020, the Minister of Finance of Japan (MOF) "added medical fields to the list of domestic industrial sectors subject to foreign investment restrictions to maintain domestic control over cutting-edge technologies including those related to dealing with the coronavirus pandemic." "The tighter controls on pharmaceutical products and advanced medical equipment under the foreign exchange and foreign trade law will take effect" on July 15, 2020. Already on April 22, 2020, the Government of Japan expressed its plan "to strictly limit foreign investment in makers of medical goods and drugs amid the novel coronavirus pandemic." "The government fears that if foreign capitals, particularly Chinese, buy up Japanese manufacturers of ventilators and other advanced medical apparatuses, it will become difficult to sufficiently check domestic production and exports of such products, whose stable supply is indispensable to national security."
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 17, 2020, it was reported that on July 16, 2020 "the Ambassador of Japan to Bangladesh, and Ms. Fatima Yasmin, Secretary, Economic Relations Division, Ministry of Finance, signed the Exchange of Notes on Japanese Grant aid "Economic and Social Development Programme"(JPY 1.0 billion, about USD 10 million) representing the respective governments." Through the agreement, the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) will send medical equipment to Bangladesh. "The medical equipment (i.e., CT Scanner, X-ray Machine) provided through this grant aid is expected to strengthen the health system of hospitals, in particular, ICUs treating COVID-19 patients in Bangladesh."
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: It was announced on July 22 that Fukuoka Prefecture had "began accepting patients with no or mild symptoms at designated hotels again".

On July 22, 2020, it was reported that the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) "is helping Bangladesh make high-quality personal protective equipment (PPE) for healthcare workers and promote those in a unique way to brand the country during the pandemic." "The JICA said: "Not only the fabrics used for these gowns are quality-assured by the standards of Directorate General of Drug Administration (DGDA), but also the final products were inspected thoroughly, using Japan’s leading technology."" "With the spread of Covid-19, the Health Ministry and the Development Partners saw an urgent need to regulate the rampant use of poor-quality PPE in Bangladesh."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
As announced on July 31, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) is implementing hospitalization measures and expanding its inspection measures to prepare for a second wave of the coronavirus. 

"We will work to increase the number of cooperating medical institutions such as clinics that collect samples.

Disseminate saliva collection that can reduce the risk and burden of specimen collection at cooperating medical institutions. To that end, we will work to establish a test system that can smoothly collect and transport samples and increase the number of samples.

Until the testing by saliva collection is available at the cooperating medical institutions, we will expand the induction of PCR tests for those returning to the home or contact of those who are considered to need testing among those who have undergone medical examination."

description: On July 31, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the Government of Japan "has agreed to receive a supply of 120 million doses of a coronavirus vaccine for 60 million people by the end of June next year from U.S. pharmaceutical giant Pfizer Inc. and its German partner BioNTech SE., if they succeed in developing the vaccine."
Fukuoka Prefecture announces on August 12, 2020 that it is coordinating with medical institutions to increase the currently secured 490 beds for COVID-19 patients to 760 beds.

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to expand the examination system, PCR tests will be made possible in 107 clinics with the cooperation of the prefectural Medical Association.
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to strengthen the acceptance system, the health of patients treated at home will be observed through a call centre; delivery of meals will be implemented; and a system will be set up to make treatment at home feel safe.

Japan, on Aug. 12th, 2020, Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced, it "will open two additional accommodation facilities [...] to accommodate patients who are mild or asymptomatic who do not require hospitalization among positive patients with new coronavirus infection". APA Hotel Asakusa Taharamachi Ekimae with 465 rooms scheduled it's opening for Aug. 13th, 2020.

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to strengthen the acceptance system, the number of beds secured at medical institutions will be raised from 200 to 425.

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to strengthen the acceptance system, the number of rooms at accommodation facilities will be raised from 210 to 340, and further expanded according to the situation.

As of August 13, the Tottori Prefecture will be providing hotel accommodation for those receiving medical treatment, which will be provides medical services by doctors and nurses with the cooperation of (public corporation) Tottori Medical Associati.on
