description: On August 16, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "the government is preparing to send hospital and public health nurses to Okinawa Prefecture." "Nurses will be sent from other prefectures as a further spread of infections is expected to strain the island prefecture’s health care system in terms of hospital beds and personnel." On August 16, 2020, Okinawa Governor Denny Tamaki "asked for such assistance at a meeting with state minister of health Gaku Hashimoto. The central government will work with the National Governors’ Association so that about 10 hospital nurses will be dispatched within a week. The number will be raised to about 50 eventually. [...] The health ministry will also consider sending to Okinawa medical workers who can handle extracorporeal membrane oxygenation, or ECMO, life support systems and taking COVID-19 patients to hospitals outside the prefecture."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: Japan, on Aug. 12th, 2020, Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced, it "will open two additional accommodation facilities [...] to accommodate patients who are mild or asymptomatic who do not require hospitalization among positive patients with new coronavirus infection". Tokyo Toranomon Tokyu REI Hotel in Minato with 431 rooms scheduled its opening for Aug. 17th, 2020.

On August 27, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced "that over 27,000 hospital beds will be secured across the country for treating patients of the novel coronavirus at the peak of infections. [...] The plans seek to balance medical institutions' responses to coronavirus patients with treatments of people with other diseases or injuries by adjusting the number of beds for patients of the virus in line with the state of infections."

On August 27, 2020, it was reported that the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) "donated PCR test kits to the Kenya Medical Research Institute (KEMRI) to boost its laboratory capacity for COVID-19 testing." The Japanese government "donated 500 COVID-19 PCR kits to be used to carry out about 50,000 tests" and "will also supply three months’ worth of chemicals necessary for clean water supply to water service providers." Additionally, "Japan has also donated 10 ambulances and assorted equipment to be used in 10 counties."

description: On August 27, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that “[a]ccording to plans drawn up by the country's 47 prefectures, more than 21,000 rooms will also be secured at accommodation facilities at the peak time for quarantining people with light or no symptoms of the virus, the ministry said. The plans seek to balance medical institutions' responses to coronavirus patients with treatments of people with other diseases or injuries by adjusting the number of beds for patients of the virus in line with the state of infections."

On August 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "adopted on Friday a plan to secure novel coronavirus vaccines for the whole population of the country by the first half of 2021. The plan was included in the government's policy for its future response to the COVID-19 crisis, adopted at a meeting of its task force on measures against the coronavirus. [...] The government will prepare a legal framework ensuring state compensation in case coronavirus vaccines cause side effects."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government “intend[s] to fundamentally enhance the structures, including securing the capacity to conduct an average of 200,000 tests per day at regional medical institutions.”

On August 25, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that it "will set up a toll-free telephone hotline at 0120-762029 on Sept. 1 to offer consultations to foreigners having trouble making a living due to the pandemic. The service will be available in 14 languages, including Japanese."

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces on September 1, 2020, that it has 1,057 rooms for overnight treatment of COVID-19 patients.
Fukuoka Prefecture announces on September 1, 2020, that it will distribute 1,845,000 surgical masks to 326 hospitals in the prefecture.
Fukuoka Prefecture announces that it will distribute 92,000 N95 masks to 57 hospitals and 1,344 clinics in the prefecture from September 7, 2020.
Fukuoka Prefecture announces that it will distribute 196,800 pairs of medical gloves to ten hospitals in the prefecture after September 7, 2020.

On September 14, 2020, it was reported that the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) donated "surgical masks, antibacterial gel, gloves, alcohol and facial masks" to the municipality of Medellín, Colombia. The donation "includes 15,000 elements that will help [the city] protect people who are on the front lines attending vulnerable communities in Medellín. This includes staff working in hospitals, detention centers, care centers for the homeless and care centers for the elderly, among others."

description: On September 25, 2020, at the 43rd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, it was announced that Japan will “install antigen quantitative test equipment, expand test booths, and secure test waiting areas in quarantine stations at airports. It is expected to secure inspection capacity of more than 10,000 people by the end of September.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 23, 2020, the Government of Japan announced that it "plans to open a website in October to book polymerase chain reaction tests for novel coronavirus infections before overseas travel. The website, named "TeCOT," will allow those planning international trips to check the necessary conditions for travel, which differ by destination, and reserve PCR tests."

On October 2, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "members of the public in Japan will be given a dose of vaccine against the novel coronavirus for free [...] in a bid to curb serious and fatal cases of infection. The policy addresses the first dose for everyone amid uncertainty at this stage over how many times a vaccine would need to be administered. Whether the policy will cover foreign residents in Japan has yet to be officially determined." "The government is trying to secure enough vaccines by the first half of 2021 to administer to all members of the public, having earmarked a budget of ¥671.4 billion ($6.4 billion)."
Fukuoka Prefecture announced that it would distribute 93,000 N95 masks to 291 hospitals in the prefecture after October 12 to prevent the spread of COVID-19.

In Tokyo, Japan on October 8, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government announced the opening of accommodation facilities for COVID-19 patients wishing to stay with their pets.  The facility opened on October 12, 2020.

On October 26, 2020, it was agreed that Japan would provide "US$ 3.8 million for medical and hospital equipment to support Zimbabwe’s COVID-19 response." The Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) will provide to the Ministry of Health and Child Care of Zimbabwe "digital X-ray systems, bedside monitors, defibrillators, electrocardiograms, blood gas analysers, laryngoscopes, and suction units, as well as hospital beds, emergency carts, autoclaves, wheelchairs and IV stands," among other equipment. "It will be installed at 4 central and 8 provincial hospitals." "It is expected that these two grants for essential equipment will enable the recipient hospitals to have increased capacities to treat patients with COVID-19 as well as other conditions."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan "approved a bill to pay all costs to administer COVID-19 vaccination to all residents in Japan, and to compensate suppliers in the event any serious side effects occur. The bill to amend the current vaccination law is in line with Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga's pledge to secure novel coronavirus vaccines for everyone in the country in the first half of next year. [...] Once the government provides vaccines free of charge, residents will be strongly advised to get vaccinated. The government may choose to offer vaccines with limited effectiveness and let people decide whether they want to receive them."

On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan agreed "to set up a hub serving as a public health center and a fever clinic for outpatients. The council[, composed by the central government, the Tokyo metropolitan government and the organizing committee of the Tokyo Games,] will start work on details, including securing staff personnel for the new bases." "The hub serving as a public health center is likely to be established in or near the athlete village, which will be used by up to some 30,000 people. If athletes or other people linked to the Tokyo Games are confirmed with the virus, the hub will conduct active epidemiological surveys in coordination with the infectious disease center and identify those who had close contact with the infected individuals."
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 27, 2020, the Government of Japan agreed "to establish an infectious disease response center to monitor the health conditions of athletes participating in the Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games in the summer of 2021. The agreement was struck at a meeting of a coordination council over the novel coronavirus epidemic among the central government, the Tokyo metropolitan government and the organizing committee of the Tokyo Games." "The infectious disease response center, to be set up as part of the organizing committee, will check the health of Olympians and Paralympians throughout the sporting events. If athletes test positive for the novel coronavirus, the center will share necessary information with their national delegations and related sports organizations."
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 22, 2020, it was announced that a "coronavirus testing center will open next month at Narita airport near Tokyo, enabling departing travelers to obtain a certificate for a negative test result within two hours." From November 2, 2020, "two facilities will be set up [...] at two terminal buildings at the airport mainly for people departing Japan" by the Nippon Medical School Foundation and Narita International Airport Corporation.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On November 17, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture announces that pregnant women who wish to be tested for COVID-19 can receive prenatal PCR tests and other tests. In addition, for pregnant women who are infected, they will be provided with support through visits or telephone calls after discharge by midwives and public health nurses.

On November 17, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture announces that pregnant women who wish to be tested for COVID-19 can receive prenatal PCR tests and other tests. In addition, for pregnant women who are infected, they will be provided with support through visits or telephone calls after discharge by midwives and public health nurses.

On November 17, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture announces that pregnant women who wish to be tested for COVID-19 can receive prenatal PCR tests and other tests. In addition, for pregnant women who are infected, they will be provided with support through visits or telephone calls after discharge by midwives and public health nurses.

On November 24, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture, Fukuoka Prefecture Mayor's Association and the Fukuoka Prefecture Municipal Association sign an agreement for the prefecture to request the dispatch of nurses from municipalities when required to respond to COVID-19.

description: On December 4, 2020, it was announced that the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) has commissioned a research group led by Kanazawa Medical University Professor Miwa Takaki to "conduct a large-scale survey on the loss of smell as a symptom of COVID-19." "The survey, which will begin later this month, will monitor the patients' olfactory functions using test kits. The group will also look at stress and other mental conditions when people suffer from the symptom for a long time." The results will be analysed by the end of March 2021.
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On December 10, 2020, NHK announced that the Ministry of Defense of Japan "plans to dispatch Self-Defense Force medical personnel to Osaka Prefecture." "The ministry will likely send a total of about seven personnel consisting of nurses and other staff. They are expected to be assigned to an existing medical emergency center as well as a facility exclusively for patients with severe COVID-19 symptoms that will open on Tuesday." "The dispatch will likely continue for roughly two weeks. The ministry is expected to decide on the dispatch on Friday after receiving an official request from Osaka Prefecture."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces on November 27, 2020 that it is seeking 3,000 volunteers to take "free antibody tests" to "estimate the rate of those who have been infected" with COVID-19 in the past. Tests will be conducted between December 16 and 24, 2020. Volunteers are limited to those who are 20+ years old and are from Kitakyushu, Fukuoka, Chikugo or Chikuho.

On October 29, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced "that it has concluded an agreement with Moderna Inc. for the supply of a vaccine against the novel coronavirus from the U.S. biopharmaceutical firm if it succeeds in developing the vaccine." "Under the agreement, Japan will receive 50 million doses of the vaccine, enough for 25 million people, from Moderna in 2021 - 40 million doses in January-June and the rest in July-September. The value of the deal was not disclosed. The ministry also concluded a contract with Japan's Takeda Pharmaceutical Co. for the distribution and sales of the vaccine in the country."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that the Government of Japan "has reached a basic agreement with AstraZeneca PLC to receive a vaccine against the novel coronavirus from the British drug giant if it is successfully developed." "Under the agreement, Japan will receive 120 million doses of the vaccine starting early next year. Of the total, 30 million doses will be supplied by the end of March. AstraZeneca will produce the vaccine also in Japan, in cooperation with JCR Pharmaceuticals Co." "The company plans to start trials in Japan later this month."

On December 9, 2020, it was announced that the government of Japan "will establish in March a center for monitoring the health of visitors from overseas during their stay amid the coronavirus pandemic, as it plans to accept small group tours ahead of the postponed Tokyo Olympic and Paralympic Games." "The health monitoring facility will also allow the games' venues to access such information to help check the health condition of visitors when the Tokyo Olympics and Paralympics are held next summer."

On January 30, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan decided to establish the "Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters". At the First Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe clarified that, concerning the 210 Japanese nationals returned to Japan from Wuhan as of January 30, 2020, the Government "intend[s] to take all possible measures in monitoring their health, while continuing to make sure that all individuals who wish to return to Japan are able to do so [and] conduct thorough health checks regardless of symptoms, including virus screening, and make government facilities such as training centers fully available for accommodation for the duration of that process."
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 3, 2020 the Diamond Princess anchored at the Yokohama port in Japan. Japanese Health authorities boarded the cruise ship to conduct an initial health review of passengers and crew. “During 3-4 February, [the] health status of all passengers and crew members were checked by questionnaire by quarantine officers, and respiratory specimens were taken from symptomatic passengers, crew, and their close contacts to test for Novel coronavirus.”

The Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare announced that from February 16, 2020 onwards PCR tests will be carried out sequentially for those under the age of 70 onboard the Diamond Princess cruise ship. Up until now, tests have been prioritised for the elderly over 70 and those who have in the same room as a person who has tested positive.

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to “(2) understan[d] the situation of infection in Japan,” it was agreed to “A) a) Identify suspected patients based on notification from physicians based on the Infectious Diseases Control Law, and conduct PCR tests when the physician deems necessary [and] identify close contacts of confirmed patients through active epidemiology surveys, in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed to “A) c) Report a suspected case of the novel coronavirus disease found at the outpatient facility for Japanese returnees and potential contacts in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law, and conduct the PCR test. As appropriate, follow hospitalization procedures in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law.”

In Niigata City, Niigata Prefecture in Japan "drive-thru-style clinic was deployed ": ""Drive-through" polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests, in which people suspected of novel coronavirus infection can be tested on the spot without getting out of their cars, have been in use at this central Japan city's public health center since March 1.“
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare announced on March 5, 2020, that "[t]ests for COVID-19 will be covered under Japan's national health insurance system starting" from March 6, 2020. "With the insurance coverage, the government will allow people to undergo testing at hospitals or contracted private testing companies without being referred to by health centers."

In order to guarantee (2) Surveillance and information gathering, it was agreed to “[i]dentify suspected disease carrier based on the notification from the doctor, and conduct tests that the doctor considers necessary.”
Oita Prefecture announced on April 1 that the Prefecture and Oita City jointly have a total COVID-19 "testing capacity of up to 132 persons per day".

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the “Government and prefectures […] will take the initiative to ensure PCR tests conducted for medical personnel, workers and inpatients.”

On 04-15-20, eighteen people at a social welfare facility in Hiroshima (Japan) have been newly confirmed infected with the novel coronavirus, the city government, and the government conducted virus tests on people related to the facility.

On April 17, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe announced that Japan will "expand testing with drive-thru facilities and general practitioners helping to collect samples." During a news conference, Abe declared that "[w]ith help from regional medical associations, we will set up testing centers. If home doctors have decided testing is necessary, test samples are taken at these centers and sent to private inspection firms."

Japan, "Yokosuka City in Kanagawa Prefecture will introduce a method called "walk-through method" to collect samples for PCR test and open a new inspection site" on Apr.17th. 40 tests can be done per day.

description: On April 20, 2020, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases of Japan (NIID) "has changed the definition of people who had close contact with patients of the COVID-19 disease, caused by the novel coronavirus. According to the new definition, people who were at a distance of one meter, enough to touch by hand, from an infected person for 15 minutes or more without taking infection prevention measures, such as wearing a face mask, two days before the person started to display symptoms or later are regarded as those with close contact with the patient."

description: On April 22, Okayama Gov. Ryuta Ibaragi (Japan) announced that the prefecture will check the temperatures of visitors from the Kinki region, where many cases of infections were reported, at a highway parking area.

description: On April 24, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Katō Katsunobu announced that MHLW "has begun checking the performance of several test kits that could be used to see the existence of coronavirus antibodies in blood samples." The Minister stated that "the ministry began the evaluation to pave the way for a quick implementation of antibody testing in Japan."

On April 26, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has decided to allow dentists to collect samples from people suspected of being infected with coronavirus in an effort to strengthen the country’s ability to conduct polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests for detecting infection." "Dentists who have taken relevant training will be able collect samples from patients at the special outpatient facilities for a certain period."

On May 2, 2020, Kitakyushu City opens a "drive-through coronavirus PCR testing center" at the Kitakyushu City Yahata Hospital. It can handle 20 to 30 tests a day.

description: On May 13, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government "began a study into whether sewage samples can be used to detect signs of a spread of novel coronavirus infections. "The metropolitan government will collect 300 milliliters of treated and untreated sewage samples once a week at 15 sewage treatment plants in the nation’s capital."

description: The government will start testing 10,000 people in Tokyo, Osaka and Miyagi prefectures for coronavirus antibodies next month as part of efforts to better understand how it spreads.

On May 24, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has decided to fully cover the cost of coronavirus PCR tests for near-term pregnant women." "Specifically, the ministry will provide subsidies to local governments subject to some conditions, which include that they decide in advance where to accept pregnant women who test positive."

On May 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 25, 2020). In order to guarantee the (2) Surveillance and Information gathering, it was agreed to “[i]dentify suspected disease carrier and conduct tests that the doctor considers necessary.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 22, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Katō Katsunobu announced that the Government of Japan"will conduct testing for coronavirus antibodies in Tokyo and two other prefectures, starting early next month for about 10,000 people." "The test will cover Tokyo and Osaka Prefecture, where the number of coronavirus cases per 100,000 people is relatively large, and Miyagi Prefecture, which has fewer cases."

description: On May 15, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) Katō Katsunobu announced that the Ministry "will conduct COVID-19 antibody testing for about 10,000 people as early as next month. The testing will cover several prefectures, including those with many coronavirus cases and those with a few cases. The ministry plans to find out whether people have antibodies against the new coronavirus and the amount of antibodies a person has."

On June 2, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "it has approved the use of saliva samples in polymerase chain reaction tests for the novel coronavirus. Saliva use is available within nine days after people start developing symptoms of COVID-19, the respiratory disease caused by the coronavirus. [...] The new method is less risky as saliva samples are enclosed in special containers by patients themselves," thus reducing the "infection risks to medical workers."

Due to a new confirmed case of COVID-19 on July 2 in Tottori City, the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) is conducting PCR tests on its citizens, as announced on July 14.  

"We are actively conducting PCR testing; if you are concerned about possible infection, please first contact the Shimane International Center’s “One Stop Center” Consultation hotline for foreign residents."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 15, 2020, the Okinawa Chubu Central Hospital (Okinawa, Japan) "started collecting specimens for antibody surveys to be carried out by the Okinawa Prefectural Government in partnership with the Okinawa Institute of Science and Technology (OIST) for a survey of the state of coronavirus infection in Okinawa. [...] The same will be carried out at the Public Kumejima Hospital. Collection of antibodies will start at prefectural hospitals in the northern and southern parts of Okinawa Island, Miyako, and Yaeyama as soon as approval is received from the ethics review committee."

On July 17, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) KATŌ Katsunobu announced that the ministry "will allow the use of saliva samples from asymptomatic people in polymerase chain reaction and antigen testing for the novel coronavirus." "The government conducted an experiment in which asymptomatic patients had mucus samples taken for PCR tests, as well as saliva samples for PCR and antigen tests. It found that the accuracy of the tests did not differ greatly."

At the event "The ROSE" in Fukuyama City, Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan), held on July 10th (Friday), multiple people with the new type coronavirus infections occurred.

"In response, the Fukuyama City Public Health Center has called on bar users to undergo PCR testing."
Fukuoka Prefecture announces on July 22, 2020 that it is introducing quicker PCR-testing kits to expand the daily testing capacity of the prefecture.
On July 25, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture begins "PCR testing for Japanese citizens who work in the U.S. bases", with a testing site established at "a community center in Okinawa City".

On August 11, 2020, Fukuoka City's Health and Environment Research Institute introduces the TMA test to perform COVID-19 testing in Fukuoka Prefecture. This test will be used along with the PCR test and bring the Prefecture's daily COVID-19 testing capacity to up to 2,450 tests per day.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency, agreed on measures to expand the medical care provisioning system and further prevent the spread of infection. In order to strengthen border measures, the TACO system at Naha Airport will be enhanced by opening up the possibility of antigen testing.

On August 28, 2020, at the 42nd Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced that the Government “will make all possible efforts to secure screening capacity for over 10,000 people at Narita Airport, Haneda Airport and Kansai International Airport by next month, and further advance the preparation of the necessary screening structures at other airports as well.”
As announced on September 28, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) will be carrying out prenatal coronavirus tests to relieve the anxiety of pregnant women from Thursday, October 1st.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: It is announced on October 29, 2020, that Fukuoka City is introducing a "PCR-test van to brace for anticipated COVID-19 clusters at residential care facilities and other places in remote areas".

On November 10, 2020, Fukuoka City announces that ahead of influenza season, it will accelerate PCR testing for "local medical and elderly care workers". The City is doing this by seeking a "special operator" who will "provide up to 2,500 virus screenings and handle related jobs" through a budget of 700 million yen.

On January 28, 2020 in Tokyo, Japan, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government installed disinfectant stations with hand sanitizer in the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Office buildings in places such as the reception and the entrance to the observation decks.

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed to “B) c) Strengthen infection control measures and secure essential goods for controlling the infection in medical institutions.”

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed to “A) c) Take general infection prevention measures at public transportation facilities, roadside stations, and other facilities where a large number of people gather.“

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed to “A) b) Take general infection prevention measures in facilities such as facilities for the elderly.”

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed to “B) d) Take general infection control measures thoroughly to prevent the infection from spreading in the facilities for the elderly if there is a suspected case of the novel coronavirus infection, while ensuring the smooth transition to hospitalized medical care for those with the high risk.”
On March 13, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture approves expenditure for disinfectant to be distributed to childcare centers and nursing homes.

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (3) Pandemic prevention, it was agreed to “[e]nsure thorough infection control measures in places including the followings”: “Medical institutions; Elderly facilities; School; Public transport; Workplace (actively promote tele-work and staggered commuting).”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On March 30, 2020, Zamami Village (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan) announced the promotion of hygienic measures on its village ferries by crew members, such as wearing of masks, hand washing, disinfection of equipments and supplies, proper coughing etiquette, and air ventilation. Customers are expected to collaborate. These measures will be effective from April 1, 2020.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect.”

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) will encourage “thorough measures to prevent infection” in the workplace.

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Japan, on Apr. 22 Tokyo government announce, that it will "implement an emergency support project (new coronavirus infectious disease emergency measures) for ensuring safety and security for taxi and bus operators."
"Measures to prevent splash infection by separating the driver's seat and rear seat in a taxi" and "infection-prevention equipment on sightseeing buses" will be installed.

On April 27, 2020, the Ministry of the Environment of Japan (MOEJ) announced that it will "provide subsidies to help restaurants introduce high-performance ventilation systems to reduce the risk of infection with the novel coronavirus." "The subsidies will be paid to cover half to two-thirds of costs to install such advanced ventilation systems, which each costs about 500,000 yen. The ministry expects that the aid will cover a total of some 3,000 ventilation systems at 800 to 1,000 locations across the nation."

description:

Continue business while ensuring that the following basic items are met.
✓ Food safety and hygiene management
✓ Cleaning and disinfection of stores and facilities
✓ Check employee health and thoroughly manage individual health and hygiene
✓ Device for setting and securing social distance

On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). The document states under "4 )Medical care, etc" that “vi) In-house infections at medical institutions and facilities for the elderly will be thoroughly prevented” by “Thoroughly avoiding the 3Cs, wearing masks, and disinfecting to prevent workers from becoming sources of infection.”

description: On July 22, 2020, at the 41th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked "people to make every effort to avoid the three Cs (closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings), refrain from activities that involve raising their voices, and take full preventive measures such as wearing face masks, hand-washing, sanitization, and ventilation."

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked business operators to comply with the "Infection Spread Prevention Guidelines" and to make use of the "shisa sticker"-system (which certifies compliance to the prefectural recommendation), "in order to minimize the impact on economic activities while strengthening infection control measures."

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked schools to "continue to make every effort to prevent infections" and families to "cooperate in observing the health of their children."

On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked managers, staff and visitors of social welfare facilities, hospitals, and other facilities where people with a high risk of serious illnesses reside, to carefully follow measures of infection prevention.

On August 18, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) announced that "All kinds of vehicles have been filled with smoke to demonstrate ventilation performance. description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures can “Promote avoiding movements of people between prefectures with relatively higher risk. Avoid going to places with ‘3Cs’.”

Note: The "3Cs" refer to closed spaces with poor ventilation, crowded and close-contact settings.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

Kyoto Prefecture (Japan) is encouraging people to make careful considerations regarding unnecessary, non-urgent travels to Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo, and Kanagawa, from June 1st until June 18th.

On May 26, the governors of the Kyushu and Yamaguchi prefectures (Japan) announced to their citizens to avoid unnecessary and urgent movements across prefectural boundaries until May 31. "From June 1st to June 18th, be careful about crossing the prefectural border to areas (e.g., Hokkaido, Saitama prefecture, Chiba prefecture, Tokyo metropolitan area, and Kanagawa prefecture) where the emergency declaration has just been lifted."

description: On July 31, 2020, Kudaka Island, Nanjo (Okinawa, Japan) issued a call for self-restraint in visiting the island. "The request takes effect on August 1 and will continue for the time being. The announcement asked for everyone's cooperation, emphasizing that Kudaka Island has a large elderly population and a fragile healthcare system, and that infections there would be an 'emergency that would threaten the continued existence of the island.'" The island called for special care in respecting the restraint during three time frames: From August 1 until August 10; from August 29 until September 5; and from September 23 until September 30, 2020.

description: Fukuoka Prefecture requested from August 5th to 7th for residents to refrain from going to restaurants and karaoke places that serve alcohol that do not comply with COVID-19 preventative measures.

On August 6, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Aichi (Japan), jointly with its own declaration of a state of emergency, asked "residents to restrain their behavior during the annual Bon holidays and refrain from traveling across prefectural borders if not urgent or necessary." "At the same time, Omura [Aichi's Governor] told reporters after the meeting that he will allow residents to travel to the neighboring prefectures of Gifu and Mie because those three prefectures in the Tokai region, including Aichi, share the same economic zone."

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed that, B) a) In communities where the number of patients continues to increase; [to] switch to broader calls for refraining from going out, while reducing the scale of active epidemiology surveys and health observations on close contacts [and to] continue and strengthen the responses to clusters of patients, depending on the situation in the community.”
Kanagawa(Japan) Prefectural Government asked people to refrain from going out unless it is necessary or urgent and to work at home as much as possible on March 26th.
Kanagawa(Japan) Prefectural Government announced on March 26th asking people to refrain from going out on March 28th, 29th.

Oita Prefecture requested on April 1 for residents to "avoid outings" "unless it is essential" from April 4. The Prefecture also noted that "younger individuals, who often do not exhibit symptoms, should exercise extra caution".
In Tokyo, Japan on April 4, 2020, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government requested Tokyo residents to refrain from leaving their homes in order to prevent more COVID-19 infections.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will at first request a self-restraint of going out while indicating the period and area as necessary. Examples of outing that are not covered by such request would include activities necessary for maintaining daily life such as visiting hospitals, purchasing food, medicine and daily necessities, going to work as necessary, exercising outdoors or taking a walk.”

On June 19, the Shimane Prefectural (Japan) government's request for refraining from going out due to a new type of coronavirus infection was completely lifted.

description: On 04/08/2020 Kumamoto Prefecture moved its coronavirus alertness level from 3 to 4. As a consequence of this, prefectural authorities demanded strongly that citizens do not travel out of the prefecture, and avoid any non-urgent and non-essential outings.

On 2020-08-05, Japan’s Subcommittee on Novel Coronavirus Infection Countermeasures published “Regarding returning home for the Bon holidays”. As part of this document, it was stated that where it is judged as difficult for the above response to the taken, people will be urged to carefully consider alternatives like online communication until infections subside. In the first place, people experiencing symptoms of a fever, etc are requested to refrain from returning home. People who have recently been to high-risk areas are also requested to make careful considerations

description: On February 16, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "attended the first Novel Coronavirus Expert Meeting at the Prime Minister’s Office" and called for contributions from "experts who are working on the front line in the respective fields, to give due consideration based on the medical and scientific perspectives, including the characteristics of the virus and other knowledge we have gathered so far", adding that the "Government will introduce further countermeasures in advance, following the advice based on the medical and scientific perspectives proposed by this expert meeting." The Expert Meeting was announced on February 14, 2020, at the Ninth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters: "in order to advance deliberations over our countermeasures based on expert knowledge even more than ever before, we will establish an expert meeting under this Headquarters, which consist of infectious disease specialists working on the frontline in their respective fields, and strengthen our responses."
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: Japan, on Feb. 25, 2020, the Hokkaido government establishes an expert team to combat Covid-19. (5 teams: the Administration Team, the Public Relations Team, the Medical System Team, the Health Activity Team, and the Consultation Team) At the governor's request, the Ministry of Health, Labour, and Welfare also sent a team of experts from the National Institute of Infectious Diseases (NIDID)."

description: On March 26, 2020, the Government of Japan established "new headquarters on the fight against the new coronavirus, under a special law that was revised recently to boost measures to prevent the spread of the virus. The launch of the new headquarters under the law is one of the procedures needed for allowing the Japanese leader to declare a state of emergency over the coronavirus outbreak. The new body will be headed by the prime minister." "The headquarters will hold its first meeting immediately after Abe's cabinet decides its launch" on the evening of March 26, 2020.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration

description: On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In this context, it was agreed that “[t]he government will work closely with the international community to collect information on the response by WHO and other countries and regions. In addition, we will actively share the knowledge obtained in Japan with related organizations such as WHO and other countries and regions, and contribute to the measures of the international community as a whole in relation to countries and regions including emerging and developing countries.”

description: On April 15, 2020, the National Institute of Technology and Evaluation of Japan (NITE) has begun evaluating "the effectiveness of “Surfactant (kitchen detergents, etc.)” “Hypochlorous acid solution (generated with the electrolysis method)” “Quaternary ammonium salt” as "options for sterilization methods using agents other than alcohol at home and in workplaces [...] in response to a request from the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry" of Japan (METI). "On April 15, 2020, a review committee session of experts was held based on the results of the research so far." "While hearing opinions from the review committee, [NETI] will implement research in the form of literature reviews, hearings with experts, and verification tests using viruses."

description:
On 6 July 2020, the Nara Prefectural Board of Education established a "talent pool" or "human resources bank" to assemble people who can work in schools at the primary, middle and high school levels as temporary teachers or support staff. Whilst schools are currently closed, many are concerned that COVID-19 will delay children's learning and so, the Nara Prefectural Board of Education will organise supplementary classes once schools reopen and ask those who apply to lead these classes and those without current teaching qualifications will be asked to provide support. Those who successfully register in the human resources bank will be able to address teacher shortages within schools if teachers are infected by COVID-19. In addition to temporary teachers, this human resources bank aims to assemble 550 learning instructors to assist with after-school supplementary classes and 140 school support staff to help with class preparations.

This human resources bank was established separately to the National Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology's human resources bank.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

*Persons who receive welfare will not be eligible for additional benefits as income reductions increase protection costs."

description:
On 8 August 2020, the governors of Japan's 47 prefectures conducted a video meeting and compiled a list of "urgent proposals" to the national government in response to COVID-19. The proposals include:
- A request to increase the amount of extraordinary grants for local governments to fund various measures against the coronavirus pandemic. 
- A revision to the special law for combating the coronavirus so that authorities can impose penalties on business operators that fail to cooperate with business-suspension requests by local governments.
- To consider extending the "Go To Travel" campaign so that tourism-related industries and local economies can sufficiently recover. In particular, the areas impacted by torrential rains in July 2020. 
- To provide more PCR test support and resources.
- To increase dissemination of information on COVID-19 to foreign nationals living in Japan through embassies and other means. 
- Strongly request measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 at US military bases. 
- To take action to eliminate prejudice, discriminatory behavior and false rumours

The governors also advise that people reconsider making trips during the Bon summer holiday season around the middle of August amid concern that the movement of people will spread the virus further.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: Cooperation among different jurisdictional entities (e.g. treaties or agreements among countries or provinces)

description: On August 25, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced that "it will allow foreigners who completed technical training courses to get jobs outside their area of specialization if they are unable to return to their countries due to the coronavirus pandemic. In early September, the agency will start accepting applications for up to one year of employment under the new program, which is intended to rescue former trainees having difficulty finding jobs in Japan at a time when many companies are scaling down their businesses and cutting job openings amid the health crisis. The agency expects applicants to find jobs in agriculture, food and beverage manufacturing and other sectors suffering severe personnel shortages."

description:
Japan, on Sep. 14, 2020, the Hokkaido government announces the establishment of the new Hokkaido Health Consultation Centre for Infectious Diseases of New Coronaviruses, which start running on Sep. 16, 2020. 
"The Hokkaido General Consultation and Returnee and Contact Centre for Infectious Diseases of New Coronaviruses in Hokkaido was directly operated by the Hokkaido Government and the Hokkaido Prefectural Public Health Center, but this time the consultation function has been outsourced to the Hokkaido Health Consultation Centre for Infectious Diseases of New Coronaviruses." Calls are free. The center provides general consultation on infectious diseases as well as, consultation for people with symptoms such as fever,  visitors, those returning home, and those who have been transferred.

Concerning the “5) Handling of schools,” it has been decided that “ii) The Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (MHLW) will provide guiding principles for nursery schools and after-school children's clubs, etc. on the downsizing of childcare and temporary closure of facilities.”

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can “Promote measures to reduce contact between people, including teleworking, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting”.

description: On 2020-07-17, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding the responses of prefectures where infections are spreading”. As part of 1) requesting co-operation from businesses in complying with infection prevention guidelines it was stated that, in prefectures where infections are spreading, restaurants with entertainment like bars and clubs and other establishments that serve alcohol will be urged to keep in mind the following point: upon complying with the guidelines, support is being carried out through a subsidy for business continuity (maximum payment of 2 million yen)
type_text: A policy providing financial support to restaurants and other alcohol-serving establishments to help them continue, provided they adhere to infection prevention guidelines
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of 4) Announcing the names of restaurants, etc for the purpose of avoiding infection spread it was decided that in the event that infected persons arise and it is difficult for the means of infection to be traced, the names of restaurants will be announced; the consent of the relevant restaurant(s) will not be necessary for the announcement. Moreover, if it is thought that the cause of the infection was due to improper implementation of infection prevention measures as indicated in the guidelines, words to that effect will be announced.
type_text: a policy regarding publicizing the names of restaurants in the event that infected persons arise and the means of infection is difficult to trace. Restaurants improperly implementing infection prevention measures will have their names publicized.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (3) efforts by shopping districts within 1) efforts towards the thorough adherence to guidelines regarding restaurants it was decided that the national government will encourage shopping districts to take the following initiative: regarding the infection prevention measures taken by restaurants, shopping district associations and the Central Federation of Societies of Commerce and Industry will co-ordinate to inform restaurants in order for business continuity support payments to be adopted.
type_text: Policy whereby restaurants will be informed about the availability of and requirements for business continuity support payments
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 2020-08-07 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding indicators and criteria related to the implementation of countermeasures in response to future changes in the infection situation”. As part of (2) reference indicators, etc within 3) indicators and criteria it was decided that in greater metropolitan areas cases of medical transport difficulty will be used as a reference indicator to see the burden on healthcare provision systems, and the days from infection to diagnosis will be used as a reference indicator to look at the monitoring system. Moreover as assistance indicators the number of installed ECMO machines, the number of other installed ventilator machines and the number of new infections among those over 60 years of age will be used for reference.
type_text: A policy that outlines different indicators to gauge the impact on healthcare systems of COVID-19. These indicators include the number of installed ECMO machines and the number of cases of medical transport difficulty.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 2020-08-07 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding indicators and criteria related to the implementation of countermeasures in response to future changes in the infection situation”. As part of (2) reference indicators, etc within 3) indicators and criteria it was decided that regarding comprehensive judgement on indicators of the situation of pressure on hospital beds it is necessary to take the latest infection speed into account and take measures when the speed is quick and meets indicators. On the other hand, during times such as when a continued expansion in infections is not apparent, judgements should not be made based solely on hospital bed occupancy but make a more comprehensive judgement.
type_text: A policy outlining how decisions should be made based on different indicators at different times
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
Japan, Hokkaido, on August 25, 2020, the Hokkaido government introduces the new governmental concept 警戒ステージ (Alert Stages): 
„The Japanese Government's Subcommittee on Countermeasures for Infectious Diseases of the Novel Coronavirus classified the infection situation into four stages, and presented guidelines for transition, as well as measures to be taken for each stage. In order to effectively control the spread of infection in our province, it is important to take measures in the stage before the number of infected people increases sharply, and therefore the indicators and measures to be taken will be established based on the actual situation in our province. In implementing these measures, we will base our efforts on a province-wide approach, as infection can occur anywhere, but we will also consider appropriate measures, such as implementing measures for specific regions and business types, as necessary, based on the situation of infection and the medical care provision system, taking into account the peculiarities of our province, which has a widely dispersed social structure. The provincial government will share the idea of this alert stage with residents and businesses, and promote measures to prevent the spread of this infectious disease and reduce the burden on the health care provision system, while working with local communities to prevent the spread of the disease as well as to balance social and economic activities.“
type_text: A new concept is implemented organizing counter measurements via a system of stages.

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces that from September 18, 2020 until January 15, 2021, restaurants can apply for a subsidy to cover expenses for infection prevention measures. This includes expenses for masks, alcohol disinfectants, non-contact thermometers, face shields, rubber gloves, acrylic plates for partitions, transparent vinyl curtain sheets, circulators and air purifiers.
type_text: Economic policy as this is a subsidy for restaurants to buy COVID infection protection equipment

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces an accommodation discount campaign to incentivize tourists to visit the prefecture. Accommodation vouchers will be provided for eligible hotels and ryokans as well as car rental between November 5, 2020 until February 28, 2021 (or as soon as vouchers sell out).
type_text: Economic policy as it is providing subsidies for accommodation

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced that discount vouchers for the "Go To Eat" program will become available on November 9, 2020. They can be used to get discounts until March 31, 2021 "at local eateries with COVID-19 Safety stickers, except for bars with guest services".
type_text: Economic policy in form of vouchers to get discount at restaurants

description: On January 21, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Ministerial Meeting called for "swift and accurate information to the citizens, and endeavour to ensure safety and security." Moreover, the Ministerial Meeting prompted to "pay sufficient attention when handling personal information of infected persons."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On January 24, 2020, the Cabinet of Japan held a Ministerial Meeting on Countermeasures Related to the Novel Coronavirus. In order to prevent the further spread of infection, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe asked "that the public strictly adhere to prevention measures against the common cold and behave calmly without overly reacting."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: In Tokyo, Japan, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government set up a telephone consultation service via a chatbot on the app LINE and a call center beginning January 29, to respond to questions and concerns of Tokyo residents  in response to outbreaks of COVID-19.

On February 7th, 2020, Hokkaido Prefecture issued statements to all forms of publics transportation, requesting that proper hygiene and safety measures be taken. All transportation employees are encouraged to wear masks and take sanitization measures.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On February 17, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "advised people to consult dedicated coronavirus-related offices at public health centers or other relevant facilities if they run a fever of 37.5 degrees Celsius or over for at least four days. Also asked to do so were people feeling lethargic or breathing difficulties severer than such conditions for influenza." In addition, the "ministry advised elderly people, those suffering from chronic diseases such as diabetes, and heart and respiratory problems, people on dialysis, those using immunosuppressive or anticancer drugs, and pregnant women to use the consultation services if their suspected new coronavirus symptoms continue for around two days, because their conditions could rapidly deteriorate if they are infected with the COVID-19 virus."

On February 21, 2020 the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare held a Press Conference on the “Situation of the novel Coronavirus Disease in the Cruise Ship off the coast of Yokohama.” At the Press Conference, infectious disease experts explained the situation based on their analysis using data obtained from the cruise ship.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: On February 21,  the Governor of Saitama Prefecture in Japan announced that "Cases of people being infected with New Coronavirus (COVID-19) are increasing, and in order to contain further spread and infection, it is essential for the citizens of Saitama to fully understand the situation and take appropriate action. Currently, there are no confirmed cases of person-to-person infection within Saitama Prefecture. In the future, it is important to confirm information and take necessary precautions."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to guarantee “(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions,” it was agreed to “d) Provide appropriate information and support to Japanese who are staying in countries where the infection is spreading.”
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs

description: On February 25, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) set up a fax consultation counter affecting the new coronavirus infectious disease for those who have difficulty hearing over the phone, such as those with hearing impairments, aphasia, and those with voice disabilities.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to guarantee “(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions,” it was agreed to “a) Provide accurate and easy-to-understand information and call on the people to encourage calm responses,” such as “provide accurate information that includes clinical information and the situations of the outbreak;” “take general infection prevention measures such as hand washing and covering their mouth when coughing;” “urge those with fever or other flu-like symptoms to take off from work or school and refrain from going out;” “raise awareness that seeking medical care without appropriate consultation due to the anxiety about potential infection may end up increasing the risk of infection, etc.”
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to guarantee “(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions,” it was agreed to “e) Provide appropriate and prompt information to the public, foreign governments and foreign tourists, to prevent the spread of infection in Japan, and to prevent rumors.”
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Japan, on Feb. 28 Akita govenor says: „We will expand public relations such as raising awareness about infection prevention and raising awareness of consultation counters through TV and newspapers.“
Oita Prefecture announced on March 3 that it would start distributing COVID-19 related information through "regular press releases and the Oita Prefecture's homepage".

description: Fukuoka Prefecture advises residents that they should protect themselves and prevent the spread of coronavirus through frequently cleaning hands "by using alcohol-based hand rub or soap and water", "when coughing and sneezing" to "cover mouth and nose" with "elbow or tissue", and to "avoid going to school or work" in the event of a fever.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Japan, on Mar. 07 Fukushima government publishes "an educational leaflet on prevention of new-type coronavirus-related infectious diseases" (revised on Feb. 25).

From March 16, "the Hokkaido Foreign Resident Support Center will provide translation support over the phone for those who wish to contact a public health center but require assistance in a language other than Japanese."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On March 19, 2020, in response with the governmental distribution of reusable face masks, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) and the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) "jointly produced a video clip on how to wash a fabric face mask."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On March 24, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) released "an easy-to-understand video clip explaining measures for addressing the novel coronavirus disease" jointly produced by the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW), the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI), the Consumer Affairs Agency of Japan (CAA) and the Ministry of Education, Culture, Sports, Science and Technology of Japan (MEXT). "Mainly targeting children, the video clip explains measures for addressing the novel coronavirus disease that every individual in Japan is able to put into practice, such as correct hand washing methods, maintaining health in daily life, appropriate room ventilation and cough etiquette, including how to make a handkerchief face mask."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: The Kanagawa(Japan) prefecture designed a sticker and encourage people to use it on SNS to support healthcare professionals who are fighting the corona virus. The announcement is made on Mar 26th, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee the “(1) Provision and sharing of information,” the following polices will be adopted:
“a) Provide accurate information and clear message for the public, promote awareness-raising to help change people’s behavior, and encourage calm response.
- Provide accurate and clear information
- Ensure implementation of basic countermeasures against infection
- Ensure that people do not go to workplace, attend school or leave home if they are sick
- Dissemination of guidelines for visits to medical institutions (call for prior telephone consultation)
- Prevent discrimination against infected persons, close contacts and medical personnel.”
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee the (1) Provision and sharing of information, the following polices will be adopted:
“b) Provide appropriate information to Japanese nationals who live in countries where infection is spreading, and those who have returned to Japan, as well as to foreign nationals living or staying in Japan.”

description: On March 31, 2020, the Minister of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) released "a video featuring popular fashion models" "to raise awareness of COVID-19 prevention among young people."

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will take effective emergency measures taking into account the characteristics of each area and provide careful explanation to the residents.”
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On April 10, Gifu prefecture starts to operate Call Center(Information Center) for providing more information related to COVID-19 to citizens.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: From April 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "has started using an illustration of "amabie," a kind of yokai, or ghost, which is believed to have the power to ward off pestilence, to call on young people for cooperation in the fight against the novel coronavirus. An awareness flyer with the illustration of amabie urging people to "stop the spread of the virus" has been posted on the ministry's website."

The Ministry of Defense of Japan (MOD) "has released an educational manual on the new coronavirus on its Joint Staff website" on April 14, 2020. "The manual, titled "To protect the safety of the people from the new coronavirus" [...] contains 39 pages of information on COVID-19. It was compiled under the supervision of the Ground Staff Office. The information is based on the knowhow of Japan's Self-Defense Forces (SDF) against infectious diseases."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 21 April 2020, the Nara Prefectural Government established an "Emergency Response Call Centre" to respond to the questions and concerns of citizens in response to the amended New Influenza Special Measures Act of 2012. The Act was amended by the National government on 13 March 2020.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Japan, on Feb. 21 Miyagi government publishes a public awareness leaflet about COVID-19 for Miyagi residents.

On 21 April 2020, the Nara Prefectural Government established an "Emergency Response Call Centre" to respond to the questions and concerns of citizens in response to the amended New Influenza Special Measures Act of 2012. The Act was amended by the National government on 13 March 2020. The Call Centre closed on 30 June 2020.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
link: NA ; http://www.pref.nara.jp/55496.htmara Prefecture ; 緊急事態措置コールセンターは、6月30日をもって終了しました

description: On April 22, 2020, the Novel Coronavirus Expert Meeting (an advisory body within the Japanese Cabinet) published a document “10 points to reduce human contact by 80%” to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The "points" or recommendations are summarised in a poster. The 10 points are:  (1) Meeting family through video calling; (2) Only one member of a household visiting the supermarket and visiting during quiet times; (3) Jogging in small numbers and choosing parks that are empty; (4) Online shopping; (5) Online drinking parties; (6) Online consultations with doctors and adjust the schedule for regular check-ups; (7) Exercise such as muscle training and yoga can be at home with videos; (8) Take-away food and drinks; (9) Work from home; and (10) Have conversations while wearing masks.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote “1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)” it was decided that “ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will inform residents using the "Ten tips" "New lifestyle practices (examples)," etc. presented by the Expert Meeting.”

Note: The documents referred to are  “10 Tips to reduce contact with people by 80%” created on April 22, 2020 and “Examples of New Lifestyle Practices” created on May 1, 2020. Both were produced after meetings of the Council of Experts, translated by the MHLW ad “Expert Meeting.”
