description: To prepare for the spread of COVID-19, Fukuoka Prefecture announces on May 29, 2020 that they have "set up a Fukuoka Corona Alert" on the prefectural website. It will provide indicators about the "number of infected people", "percentage of persons whose infection route is unknown", "hospital bed occupancy rate" and "occupancy rate for severe conditions".
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 9, Fukuoka Prefecture shared "revised guidelines" in preparation for a "disaster combined with circumstances involving the spread of COVID-19" and have advised "cities and towns" to revise their manuals "in accordance with the new guidelines by the end of May". Guidelines call for the avoidance of "closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings" as well as "the use of additional accommodation facilities".
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
On 17 June 2020, Nara Prefecture in the lead up to the annual monsoon season/ rainy season during which Japan is prone is disasters, shared on their website evacuation guidelines and procedures. Furthermore, these guidelines include recommendations on how to prevent the spread of covid-19 during evacuation and refuge. 

In addition to basic stockpiling, Nara Prefecture asks citizens to prepare: masks, a thermometer, plastic bags, disinfectant solution/ hand sanitiser, wet tissues and towels.

In evacuation shelters, they ask citizens to wear masks, practicing good hygiene such as hand washing and cooperate with others in the shelter. To support this, the Prefecture has attached guides on hand washing,  hand washing without water, cough etiquette and hygiene management of shelter toilets. 

This policy includes and supports material produced by the National Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description:
On June 19, 2020, the Japan Tourism Agency, that exists under the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism announced the development of guidelines called “New Travel Etiquette - Avoid the risk of infection to have a safe and enjoyable journey” by the Travel Liaison Committee. The Travel Liaison Committee consists of industry bodies related to the travel industry. 

The “New Travel Etiquette” guidelines were published on the website of the Japan Association of Travel Agents. 

The guidelines list precautions under five categories: The Basics of the New Style of Travel; Travelling/ Moving; During meals;  Accommodation; Tourist Attractions; and Shopping.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On June 19, 2020, the Japan Tourism Agency, that exists under the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism announced the development of guidelines called “New Travel Etiquette - Avoid the risk of infection to have a safe and enjoyable journey” by the Travel Liaison Committee. The Travel Liaison Committee consists of industry bodies related to the travel industry. 

The “New Travel Etiquette” guidelines were published on the website of the Japan Association of Travel Agents. 

The guidelines list precautions under five categories: The Basics of the New Style of Travel; Travelling/ Moving; During meals;  Accommodation; Tourist Attractions; and Shopping.

On September 29, 2020 new posters were created. They consist of four individual posters for different situations: Transportation/ Eating and Drinking during Travel/ Accommodation/ Visiting Tourist Facilities and Shopping. As well as a second version of the general guidelines poster, which highlights six key points travellers should remember to contribute to enjoyable travels for everyone.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The Tottori Prefecture (Japan) announced on June 23 to its citizens to install the new coronavirus contact confirmation app "COCOA".
　"The new coronavirus contact confirmation application "COCOA" of the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is a smartphone application that allows you to receive notifications about the possibility of contact with a person infected with a new coronavirus infection."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On June 25, 2020, the review committee session of experts of the National Institute of Technology and Evaluation of Japan (NITE) "held its fifth (final) meeting and decided that the following disinfection substances are effective at removing the novel coronavirus.
(1) Surfactants: Sodium linear alkylbenzene sulfonate (0.1% or more); Alkyl glycoside (0.1% or more); Alkylamine oxide (0.05% or more); Benzalkonium chloride (0.05% or more); Benzethonium chloride (0.05% or more); Dialkyldimethyl ammonium chloride (0.01% or more); Polyoxyethylene alkylether (0.2% or more); Pure-soap component (potassium salts of fatty acids; 0.24% or more) (newly added on June 25, 2020); and Pure-soap component (sodium of fatty acids; 0.22% or more) (newly added on June 25, 2020).
(2) Hypochlorous acid solution (at chlorine concentration of 35ppm or more) (newly added on June 25, 2020)."
Accordingly, on June 26, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced the results and published several explanatory materials "while NITE posted a list of detergents containing these surfactants on its website. [...] METI hopes that many of the general public will make use of these materials."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 3, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) published "a list of travel medicine clinics, as of July 2, 2020, at which people are able to obtain a certificate certifying a negative result of a PCR test."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On July 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on the public not to panic after a record 224 new coronavirus cases were reported in Tokyo." ""We've been closely monitoring the infection situation with a high sense of tension," Abe said. He called on the public, especially young people, to take steps to avoid infection."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On July 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on the public not to panic after a record 224 new coronavirus cases were reported in Tokyo," declaring that the "current situation is not as tense as it was in April, when the government declared a state of emergency over the pandemic." Prime Minister Abe Shinzō "called on the public, especially young people, to take steps to avoid infection."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On July 22, 2020, the Government of Japan kicked off the "Go To Travel campaign", a discount travel campaign. The campaign will be financed with ¥1.35 trillion yen "to promote domestic travel by anyone to any destination [within Japan] they wished with an up to a 50 percent discount via deals and vouchers. [...] But after a spike in coronavirus cases in Tokyo, the government announced a sudden decision to exclude travel to and from the capital." "The government hopes to support the tourism industry, hurt by the coronavirus pandemic, while taking care not to spread the virus further. Travel and accommodation businesses are required to take full precautions."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (3) efforts in coordination with universities, etc within 3) Infection prevention measures at workplaces and universities, etc it was decided that universities will be strongly urged to tell students to pay attention to their behaviour based on the fact that a large number of infections among young people and infections caused by lodging and dining together have been confirmed.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (1) promoting a change in behaviour suitable for the “New Everyday” within 2) Efforts to encourage restaurant users adopt behaviour to protect themselves it was decided that people will be encouraged to consistently wear masks, wash their hands, use sanitiser and ensure ventilation
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (1) efforts by local government within 1) efforts towards the thorough adherence to guidelines regarding restaurants it was decided that the national government will encourage local governments to implement the following policy: make use of opportunities when restaurants, etc register for or renew their business permits to distribute and make businesspeople aware of guidelines
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (2) efforts by industry groups within 1) efforts towards the thorough adherence to guidelines regarding restaurants it was decided that the national government will encourage industry groups to take the following initiative: industry groups will make their members aware of guidelines and carry out the encouragement and advice necessary for compliance with guidelines.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (1) efforts by local government within 1) efforts towards the thorough adherence to guidelines regarding restaurants it was decided that the national government will encourage local governments to implement the following policy: when carrying out on-site inspections to determine buildings’ thorough compliance with sanitary management standards, if restaurants are included among the tenants, distribute guidelines to the specific building owners.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On August 5, 2020, Okinawa Prefecture (Japan) opened two official LINE accounts ("Okinawa Prefecture Official LINE Account" and "Okinawa Prefecture - Corona Countermeasures Personal Support") in order to send institutional information concerning the prefecture and spread information about new coronavirus infectious disease.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Kagoshima Prefecture set up a COVID-19 consultation call center on August 6 to respond to COVID-19 related enquiries from citizens and businesses. The line is available 24/7 and a fax option is also available. There is also 24/7 support available in English, Chinese, Korean, Spanish and Portuguese. Support in Vietnamese and Thai is available on weekdays from 10am to 6pm.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On August 19, the Tottori Prefecture (Japan) established a hygiene counseling service for businesses that operate accommodation facilities, restaurants, etc., and are confused about measures to prevent infection, measures to take if an infected person occurs, and refrain from reducing sales.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On August 21, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) opened a consultation dial to receive appropriate advice and information from dedicated staff 24 hours a day, directly for various consultations regarding symptoms related to new-type coronavirus infectious diseases, infection prevention, inspection methods, etc.
type_sub_cat: Both Disseminating and Gathering information related to COVID-19
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Fukuoka Prefecture requests residents from August 22, 2020, to "refrain from using restaurants", that "do not comply" with COVID-19 guidelines. i.e. those that do not display the prefectural government's "Infection Prevention" sticker. Restaurants that are covered include those with "close contact", serve alcohol, karaoke places that serve alcohol as well as other restaurants that serve alcoholic beverages.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On August 24 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events after September 1”. As part of 2) Points of note regarding holding events it was decided that each prefecture will call event participants and event organisers to attention regarding infection prevention measures.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On August 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) "released on its website guidelines for mask usage by preschool children to help prevent coronavirus infections" saying that "children under two years of age should not wear face masks, citing the risk of choking and heatstroke."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces on September 18, 2020, that residents can check if shops and facilities are compliant with COVID infection prevention measures through searching on an online website.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On September 29, 2020 additional “New Travel Etiquette” documents were created and shared on the website of the Japan Association of Travel Agents, created by the Travel Liaison Committee. The new posters break down the guidelines into four various situations: Transportation/ Eating and Drinking during Travel/ Accommodation/ Visiting Tourist Facilities and Shopping. The second version of the general guidelines poster highlights six key points travellers should remember to contribute to enjoyable travels for everyone.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 23, 2020, the Government of Japan "decided to request major business organizations to show flexibility and extend the holiday period to allow employees to take breaks until Coming-of-Age Day" on January 11, 2020. "Yasutoshi Nishimura, the economic revitalization minister who is also in charge of the government’s handling of the pandemic, told reporters after the meeting that public employees as well as members of Keidanren (Japan Federation of Economic Organizations), the nation's largest business group, and other leading business groups will be asked to cooperate."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On October 26, 2020, Japanese health officials urged "people in all age groups to get influenza shots amid concerns about simultaneous outbreaks of flu and coronavirus infections." "The health ministry advised that people aged 65 or older should be given flu shots first from October 1. Starting on Monday, the ministry is advising other age groups to get vaccinated. [...] Ministry officials are urging medical workers, people with preexisting conditions, pregnant women and children ranging from six months old to second graders to get vaccinated early."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On December 8, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture reminds "people of the importance of ventilation during... winter" to prevent the spread of COVID-19.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On February 1, 2020, at the Fourth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe declared that from February 1, 2020, "it has become possible to implement measures as a Designated Infectious Disease, including hospitalization for the patients infected by the novel coronavirus."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On February 5, 2020 upon identifying ten cases of covid-19 upon the Diamond Princess cruise ship, the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare announced a 14-day health observation period (quarantine) due to the severity of the infection.Passengers confirmed to be free from infection began disembarking on Day 15 (February 19) of the quarantine.

On February 12, 2020, during the Seventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, the Government of Japan "has made a "high-level" political decision to flexibly interpret existing legislation", "open[ing] the way to forcibly quarantining those suspected of having the virus by broadly interpreting relevant legislation."
target_geog_level: All countries

description: On February 12, 2020, during the Seventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, the Government of Japan "has made a "high-level" political decision to flexibly interpret existing legislation", "open[ing] the way to forcibly quarantining those suspected of having the virus by broadly interpreting relevant legislation."

description: On February 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that "Japan will revise an ordinance to enable the isolation of those infected or suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus during quarantine". From February 14, 2020, authorities will be allowed "to conduct compulsory hospitalization of infected people with no symptoms. [...] Under the revised ordinance, authorities will be able to isolate infected people through hospitalization and make people suspected of being infected stay at designated facilities, during the quarantine procedures before they enter the country. As people with no symptoms will be subject to the compulsory hospitalization measure, the government will cover their medical costs."
target_geog_level: All countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: On February 13, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) announced that, from February 14, 2020 onwards, "the isolation of those infected or suspected of being infected with the new coronavirus during quarantine" will be allowed. Authorities will also be allowed "to conduct compulsory hospitalization of infected people with no symptoms." "Under the revised ordinance, authorities will be able to isolate infected people through hospitalization and make people suspected of being infected stay at designated facilities, during the quarantine procedures before they enter the country. As people with no symptoms will be subject to the compulsory hospitalization measure, the government will cover their medical costs."
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On February 13, 2020 the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare announced that certain passengers onboard the Diamond Princess will be allowed to voluntarily disembark. This policy identifies elderly persons (over the age of 80) with chronic diseases and existing health conditions whose health may further deteriorate due to the quarantine conditions as persons who are permitted to disembark. "If they test negative for the virus, they can leave the ship and stay at government-prepared accommodation facilities starting on Feb. 14. If their results are positive, they will be sent to medical institutions."
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)

description: On February 18, 2020, at the Eleventh Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe invited "the public [...] to refrain from going outside, taking leave from school or work, when experiencing symptoms of a cold, such as a fever. [...] Creating an environment that makes it easy for students and employees to take days off is crucial and I would like to ask cooperation in this regard. Making use of means like tele-working is another effective approach."
From February 19, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture called for residents with cold symptoms such as a fever to take a break from school or work and rest at home.

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(5) border control measures,” it was agreed that, “from the viewpoint of securing medical resources in Japan, quarantine operations will be shifted, according to measures to prevent the spread of infection in Japan and systems for providing medical care.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Ministry/Department of Foreign Affairs,Ministry/Department of Justice

description: On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order for the “(4) health system to deliver medical care,” it was agreed that “B) a) patients with mild flu-like symptoms should stay at home unless otherwise specified, and seek medical care after consulting the call center or a family doctor, if their conditions change.”

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. As for “(3) measures to control the infection,” it was agreed to “A) a) Take the following measures in accordance with the Infectious Diseases Control Law if a patient is identified by notification of a physician or other means: the active epidemiology survey to be conducted by the public health center; and close contacts to be monitored for their health conditions and requested to refrain from going out. The local government shall use active epidemiology surveys to identify a cluster based on individual patient outbreaks in cooperation with the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare and experts, and request the necessary measures including closure of the related facilities and voluntary restraint of events if there is a possibility that such a cluster exists.”

On February 26, the Tottori prefecture (Japan) urged all persons entering Japan from any region where there is a high risk of new coronavirus pneumonia infection, notably China, to apply for quarantine if they are experiencing any symptoms of cough or fever.
type_sub_cat: Government Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at a government hotel or facility)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, on Feb. 27 Fukushima government requests residents showing symptoms to refrain from going out from Feb. 27 until Mar. 12.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: Japan, on Feb. 28, 2020, the Hokkaido governor request people to refrain from going outside the weekend from Feb. 29 until Mar. 01.

Fukuoka Prefecture announced on March 19, 2020, that returnees from overseas who test negative to COVID are requested to stay for 14 days at a place designated by the quarantine station chief who conducted the COVID test such as home.
Japan, on Mar. 19 Yamagata government requests all people coming from abroad  to the prefecture to self-quarantine for two weeks.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike requested on March 25, 2020 "that residents refrain from going outside [...] for nonessential reasons" on the weekend of March 28 and 29, 2020.

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to “[e]stablish a system for those with mild symptoms to be cared at home, in areas where there is a risk that an increase in patients of the Coronavirus may interfere with the provision of hospitalized medical care for other severely ill patients.”
Japan, on Mar. 28 Akita govenor requests people „who have returned to or come to the prefecture from areas where many infected people such as Tokyo“ for self-quarantine for about 2 weeks.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
target_province: Tokyo, others not specifies (hot spot areas)_Akita

description: On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). As for (4) Medicare, it was agreed to “[p]erform tests at the discretion of the doctor and, if a patient is found, provide recommendations and necessary measures for admission to hospitals to provide appropriate medical care.”

description: On April 7, 2020, the Welfare Department of Tarama Island and Tarama Clinic asked residents to "refrain from visiting relatives from outside the island. If you are returning from outside the island on prefectural high school leave, avoid routine health checks and interaction with friends and relatives." "Regarding homecoming high school children due to the prefectural extension of public high school closure, please do not interact with friends or people on the island. Return home and leave only for basic shopping." [loose translation from Japanese]

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[i]solate a suspected case immediately and implement infection countermeasures under the guidance of public health centers, in case of suspecting a new case of COVID-19 infection from hospitalized patients or users.”

In Tokyo, Japan on February 23, 2020, the Ghibli Museum, located in Mitaka City, Tokyo Metropolis, announced its closure from February 25, 2020 until March 17, 2020, "in mutual agreement with the City of Mitaka" and "in accordance to the Tokyo Metropolitan Government's decision to cancel or postpone its major indoor events for the next three weeks in order to curb the spread of the Novel Coronavirus (Covid-19)."

On February 25, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control”. In order to guarantee “(1) information sharing with individuals, private sectors, and regions”, it was agreed to “b) Urge companies to encourage employees and other personnel to take leave if they have fever or other flu-like symptoms, and promote teleworking and staggering commuting hours, in order to reduce the opportunities for contact with patients and infected persons.”

description:
Oita Prefecture announced on April 1 that "workplaces that remain open for essential social and economic services" should: 
1. "Thoroughly carry out precautionary measures (e.g. handwashing, good cough etiquette) in an out of the office and during commute" 
2. "Proactively incorporate telecommuting, staggered work hours and commute on bicycle"
3.  If staff show "fever or symptoms of cold", "refrain from working (or make alternative work arrangements such as telecommuting) and remain at home"
4. "Employ alternative work arrangements such as video conferences to cut back travel on business trips"

description:
The Yamaguchi prefecture (Japan) has requested all related businesses to take leave as described in Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Act on Special Measures against Countermeasures against New Influenza, etc., announced on April 20. 

"From April 16th to May 6th, Reiwa, the "Emergency Declaration" was issued to all prefectures, and we are strongly calling for the residents of the prefecture to refrain from going out unnecessarily and urgently. There is concern about an increase in the inflow of people from neighboring prefectures, which are expanding rapidly, to entertainment and amusement facilities."
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is closed/locked down
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On 21 April 2020, following the 5th Nara Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Diseases Control Headquarters Meeting, a number of restrictions were implemented to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The Prefecture asks that from April 23rd to May 6th, certain facilities suspend their activities in accordance with Article 24, Paragraph 9 of the Special Measures Law. These include: recreation facilities, exercise and amusement facilities, theaters, private cram schools, driving schools, meeting/ exhibition facilities, commercial facilities other than stores that sell daily-necessities (essential goods).
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is closed/locked down

description:
On 2020-04-23, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan's Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled "Regarding Preventing the Spread of Novel Coronavirus in Shopping Districts and Supermarkets, etc". In this document it was stated that prefectures where it is judged that people are gathering in large numbers in supermarkets, these prefectures would call on the relevant businesses to take the following policies:
* Implement socially-distanced queuing when entering the business and paying
* Disinfection/sterilization of shared spaces, thorough implementtation of hand sanitiser when entering and leaving
* Ensure space when talking, erect partitions when facing each other
* When the business becomes crowded, appropriately implement entry restrictions and one-way guidance in the establishment.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
On 21 April 2020, following the 5th Nara Prefectural Coronavirus Infectious Diseases Control Headquarters Meeting, a number of restrictions were implemented to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Although some facilities were asked to suspend their activities between 23 April and 6 May (which encompasses Golden Week), some are asked to remain open. Facilities that are requested to continue operating include: medical facilities, facilities for daily necessities (encompassing wholesale markets, grocery stores, essential goods sections in department stores, hardware stores, supermarkets, convenience stores), accomodation facilities, transportation, factories, financial institutions (banks, stock exchanges, insurance companies), media organisations, funeral homes, public baths, pawnshops, veterinarians, beauty salons, laundromats and garbage disposal related facilities.

However, these facilities/ services are asked to implement appropriate infection control measures or encourage remote work where possible. 

Restaurants and other hospitality businesses (including taverns) are also allowed to open, but with infection control measures and are asked to shorten opening hours and terminate the sale of alcoholic beverages at 7pm.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description:
On April 23, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy
of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, "issued guidelines on what kind of steps governors can take to get business owners that continue to ignore government requests to suspend their operations." "The guidelines say governors are authorized to issue stronger "requests" or "instructions" to those who refuse to comply with initial requests without legitimate reasons.
The names and addresses of the businesses given such stronger warnings will be disclosed online or by other means."
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: On April 24, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Osaka, Japan, "revealed the names of six pachinko pinball parlors that have not followed its request to shut down in the fight against the novel coronavirus. description:
On April 25, the Yamaguchi prefecture (Japan) announced this: 
"To the citizens of the Yamaguchi prefecture, in order to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infectious diseases, refrain from going out, except for those who need to visit the hospital, purchase food, medicines and daily necessities, and keep outdoor activities such as exercise and walking. 

On the other hand, it has been pointed out that it is necessary to prevent infections in places such as supermarkets, shopping malls, and parks that are used by many people. Please take note of the following and cooperate with us in preventing the spread of infections.
* Keep the number of people small and avoid crowds, and keep the distance between people appropriately.
* Observe the request to prevent infection at the place of use."
institution_status: This type of business  ("Shopping Centers") is allowed to open with conditions

description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that "i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks."
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is closed/locked down
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4 2020 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding the Maintenance and Relaxation, etc of State of Emergency Measures”. With regards to (2) Designated prefectures other than the Prefectures under Special Caution as part of 3) restrictions on the use of facilities it was decided that, with regards to the types of facility where the 3Cs can be avoided and clusters have not been observed, these prefectures will consider lifting or relaxing the demand for restrictions on the use of facilities under the condition that infection prevention measures like the use of masks, the installation of sanitiser equipment and distancing measures are thoroughly implemented.

description: On May 4 2020 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding the Maintenance and Relaxation, etc of State of Emergency Measures”. With regards to (2) Designated prefectures other than the Prefectures under Special Caution as part of 3) restrictions on the use of facilities it was decided that in relation to amusement centres these prefectures will make appropriate judgements while keeping these venues’ ease of generating the 3Cs and infection situation in mind. However in the event that prefectures, because of the thorough implementation of infection prevention measures,judged these facilities to not be environments where the 3Cs might easily arise, it will be possible for them to consider relaxing or lifting restrictions on the use of facilities for these venues. These infection prevention measures include calling for customers not to speak loudly and lowering the volume of background music and machines, ensuring space between people (2 meters where possible), sanitising when customers move places, the use of masks and ensuring an environment where staff can ensure that customers are not speaking loudly amongst themselves.
institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions

description: On May 14, 2020, the Japan Business Federation (Keidanren, 経団連) released guidelines "for protecting workers from COVID-19 are expected to be referred to when companies resume business activities while taking precautionary measures, following the government's lifting of the coronavirus state of emergency for most of the country's 47 prefectures. The guidelines are intended for long-term use at least until treatment for the disease is established and a vaccine is developed." Moreover, it "called on member companies to introduce a four-day workweek system to reduce coronavirus infection risks" and suggested "further promotion of remote working, staggered commuting and social-distancing measures in workplaces." Keidanren asked companies to "take measures, keeping in mind that steps taken at workplaces will lead to the prevention of a further spread of the virus across the entire society."

In order to regulate ‘4) Going to workplaces’ it was noted that, ‘ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures will need sustainable measures in future, Measures to reduce contact with people, including teleworking, working in rotations, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting, will continue.’

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (2) prefectures not subject to emergency measures as part of 3) restrictions on the use of facilities it was decided that, as outlined in the Basic Policies, prefectures will call for the necessary co-operation from the managers of facilities where clusters are occurring or where the 3Cs are present, based on the infection situation. This co-operation can include the implementation of distancing measures between people, ventilation and the use of sanitiser.

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “4) Going to workplaces” it was decided that “ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama and Kanagawa] will need sustainable measures in future, businesses engaged in work essential for ensuring the stability of people's lives and the national economy (examples given in the attachment) as well as businesses supporting such work, must continue operating, depending on the characteristics of the businesses, while taking comprehensive measures to prevent the spread of infections, including measures to avoid the 3Cs.

From the attachment: Businesses engaged in essential work include those: Maintaining Medical System; Continuing to protect those in need; Securing stable lives of the people; Maintaining the stability of the society; and Others (those who will have difficulty stopping the production line; operators who produce essentials).
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “4) Going to workplaces” it was decided that “ii) Based on the expectation that all designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama and Kanagawa] will need sustainable measures in future, workplaces will be encouraged to put thorough measures in place to prevent infections and avoid the 3Cs.”

Note: The "3Cs" refer to closed spaces with poor ventilation, crowded and close-contact settings.

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can “Promote measures to reduce contact between people, including teleworking, staggered work hours, and bicycle commuting”.

description: On May 25 2020, Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Prefectural Response during the Transition”. With regards to (2) the types of facility where clusters have occurred so far as part of 4) restrictions on the use of facilities, it was decided that until the end of May co-operation in restrictions on the use of facilities will be called for as per the office communication dated May 14. These restrictions include the use of masks and face guards for customers and employees, disinfection and the distancing of seating (2 meters if possible).

description: On 2020-07-17, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding the responses of prefectures where infections are spreading”. As part of 1) requesting co-operation from businesses in complying with infection prevention guidelines it was stated that, in prefectures where infections are spreading, restaurants with entertainment like bars and clubs and other establishments that serve alcohol will be urged to keep in mind the following point: regardless of the establishment’s size, apply policies outlined in the “Food Service Industry Guidelines” including “erect partitions between tables or where possible ensure an over 2 meter (minimum 1 meter) space” and “if using private rooms, carry out sufficient ventilation”

institution_status: This type of business  ("Commercial Businesses") is allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 2020-07-17, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding the responses of prefectures where infections are spreading”. As part of 2) Requesting co-operation in refraining from the use of specific restaurants which are not complying with guidelines it was stated that in order for users to confirm restaurants’ compliance with guidelines, in each prefecture efforts to distribute stickers and encourage independent declarations on the part of business persons will be promoted
institution_status: This type of business  ("Restaurants") is allowed to open with conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (2) efforts by industry groups within 1) efforts towards the thorough adherence to guidelines regarding restaurants it was decided that the national government will encourage industry groups to take the following initiative: industry groups will encourage their members to urge their employees and users to download the COCOA contact tracing app. Moreover, in the case that a local government is implementing its own system for informing the users of businesses where infections have emerged, restaurants will be encouraged to use this system.

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "if an exporter’s certificate of export permission or certificate of export approval is set to expire due to a delay or other disruptions in target exports resulting from the novel coronavirus epidemic, the exporter is permitted to file a request to extend the validity period of the certificate. Please file such requests before the validity of the certificate expires."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "if an importer’s certificate of import approval is set to expire due to delays or other disruptions in target imports resulting from the novel coronavirus epidemic, the importer is permitted to file a request for an extension of the validity period of the certificate." “In filing such requests, importers are ordinarily required to submit the official document establishing the need for the extension of the certificate. However, until March 31, 2020, if it is difficult for importers to obtain such a document, importers are permitted to file an alternative document.”
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "concerning the fulfillment of the permission conditions shown in a certificate of export permission for goods destined for China (e.g., reports on installation of machine tools), if the deadline of the fulfillment of the conditions is a date before March 31, 2020, the government of Japan will automatically extend the deadline to March 31, 2020,** for all exporters. Such exporters are not required to file a request to change registered data when extending the deadline. However, they are required to fulfill the conditions as swiftly as possible if they are able to execute them before March 31, 2020.”
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "in cases where certificates issued by the government of Japan and other organizations under certain treaties or agreements expire, the government of Japan cannot extend the valid period of these certificates because of the restrictions under such treaties. Exporters with expired certificates are required to file requests to re-issue such certificates anew."
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On February 14, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that it "expects delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the novel coronavirus epidemic. As responses to such delays, METI compiled the following notable items related to trade controls, including new, special treatments." In this regard, "if an importer’s tariff quota certificate is set to expire due to a delay or other disruption in target imports resulting from the novel coronavirus epidemic, the importer is permitted to file a request for an extension of the validity period of the certificate within a period not exceeding 30 days from the date following the expiration date of the certificate. Please file such request before the validity of the certificate expires (until March 31, 2020)." “In filing such request, importers are ordinarily required to submit a “document establishing the difficulties in making an import declaration of goods subject to tariff quota within the validity period of the tariff quota certificate. […] However, if it is difficult for importers to obtain such a document, importers are permitted to file an alternative document for the period until March 31, 2020.”
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Issuing of permits/certificates and/or processing of government documents
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 5, 2020, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan (METI) announced that "in response to expected delays and other disruptions in imports and exports as a result of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry (METI) has summarized trade control related procedural notifications, including some new special treatments." "Importers are expected to apply for extension of their import license BEFORE IT ACTUALLY EXPIRES in case such license is set to expire due to delays or other disruptions as a result of the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19)." "For applicants having difficulty in obtaining documents demonstrating necessity of license extensions, METI will alternatively accept an importer’s written self-statement explaining [i] detailed background of such necessity for extension and [ii] difficulty in obtaining such documents until June 30, 2020."

description: Since the declaration of state of emergency on April 7, 2020, the offices of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) have decreased "the number of people who commute to work by utilizing teleworking" and implemented "measures for double shifts in various divisions". Large-scale trainings for new personnel and large meetings are being avoided. Within its diplomatic missions abroad, MOFA has been promoting infection control measures "such as hand-washing and cough etiquette, utilizing teleworking and staggered work hours, and preventing suspension of functions by dividing personnel into teams and coming to work". In addition, "various business trips and the like have of course been reduced to the absolute minimum amount necessary", and officials "either work at home or commute to work" according to a "split-team structure". Over-the-counter services have been affected by "shortened counter hours", the introduction of "appointment systems", and extensions to "document processing times".
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “should strongly promote teleworking. Even in case of going to work, efforts to reduce contact with people, such as staggered work hours and bicycle commuting will be promoted even more strongly than ever.”
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services

description: On April 7 and April 9, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) issued declarations concerning “MOFA’s structure and efforts in the case of the declaration of a state of emergency,” which was realised on  Planned and adopted measures include “teleworking”, “the introduction of a split-team structure” where “personnel [is divided] into two teams that either work at home or commute to work, including for diplomatic missions,” and decrease of “the total number of hours spent working in person at MOFA.” Moreover, “diplomatic missions have been taking infection control measures in the same way as MOFA including thoroughly promoting practices such as handwashing and cough etiquette, utilizing teleworking and staggered work hours, and preventing suspension of functions by dividing personnel into teams and coming to work. Also, various business trips and the like have of course been reduced to the absolute minimum amount necessary.”
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
type_sub_cat: Regulated government working hours (e.g. work from home policies for government workers)
institution_status: This service is no longer provided by the government
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to implement ‘3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later) it was decided that ‘i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions (Tokyo, Osaka, Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Kyoto, Hyogo) will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks.’
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with no conditions attached
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). “3) Restrictions on using facilities (related to restricted events mentioned earlier, excluding schools and other facilities mentioned later)” requires “i) Prefectures under Specific Cautions [Tokyo, Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, and Kanagawa] will issue requests to follow restrictions on the use of facilities that may cause infections to spread. If such requests are not met and no justifiable reason is given, prefectures will issue further requests and instructions based on the Act, and they shall publicize the fact. Additionally, considering the impact of the extended measures on society, the economy, and the lives and health of the citizens, the Governors of each prefecture may make appropriate decisions on opening facilities such as museums, art galleries, libraries and outdoor parks.”
type: Restriction and Regulation of Government Services
institution_status: This service provided by the government is provided with conditions atttached

description:
On 8 May 2020, Nara Prefecture announced the temporary closure of "Nara Mahoroba-kan"- a souvenir store and tourism centre. The "Nara Mahoroba-kan" was be closed until May 31st. 
   
From 1 June "Nara Mahorobakan" will reopen but with reduced opening hours. Between June 1st to 12th, the business hours will be 11:00 to 19:00 (Usually from 10:30 to 19:30).

description: On March 1, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) requested to the people of Japan to make efforts to “minimize the spread of infection in the country by preventing one cluster of patients from creating another cluster,” reminding that infections might spread “in areas such as athletic gyms, houseboats, buffet style meals, mahjong rooms, guest houses at ski resorts, and air-tight provisional tents,” and thus inviting to “avoid gathering in groups in areas with poor ventilation where people gather closely together.”

On February 17, 2020 in Tokyo, Japan, the Tokyo Marathon Foundation announced that the Tokyo Marathon 2020 on March 1, 2020 "will be held only for the marathon elites and the wheelchair elites", canceling the mass participation element of the race.

description: On March 1, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) requested to the people of Japan to make efforts to “minimize the spread of infection in the country by preventing one cluster of patients from creating another cluster,” inviting “organizers of events should consider the necessity of holding any event, whether big or small, due to the high risk of infection posed by spaces with poor ventilation, and environments where people communicate at close range. description: On April 2, 2020, "the Okinawa Medical Association (Tetsuyoshi Asato, committee chair) announced [...] that, with the opening of the tomb sweeping festival (shimi) season taking place this weekend, they are asking people [...] to keep gatherings small." description: Japan, on Apr. 02 Yamagata government requests to refrain from gatherings over the weekend : „Over the weekend, please do not gather in large groups and reduce the number of people you have contact with.“
Fukuoka Prefecture requests that residents "avoid poorly ventilated spaces, crowded spaces, and close contact with people" from April 2.

Oita Prefecture requested from April 4 for "all residents" to avoid "events that involve crowds unless it is essential". Furthermore, "younger individuals, who often do not exhibit symptoms, should exercise extra caution".

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, designated prefectures (Tokyo, Osaka, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Hyogo, and Fukuoka) “will make request to restrict the holding of events that may lead to the spread of infection. When a request is not met with no justifiable reason, instructions will be issued and these requests and instructions will be made public.”

description: "Japan's Imperial Household Agency said [on April 13, 2020] that it has decided to cancel this year's Imperial spring garden party, scheduled for May 27, because of the spread of the novel coronavirus. The event was due to be hosted by Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako. The agency holds a garden party hosted by the country's Emperor and Empress in spring and autumn every year, at the Akasaka Imperial estate in the Motoakasaka district in Tokyo's Minato Ward, with some 2,000 guests."

description: On April 14, Fukui Prefecture Government requests citizens to refrain from going out until May 6.

"This year's high school meet for 30 sports was expected to bring together 30,000 people."

description: "Fukuoka Prefecture announced parking-lot closures" at four parks (Ohori, Nishi, Najima Sports, Kasuga Parks) "during the Golden Week holidays" from April 29 to May 6.

On May 1, 2020, the Immigration Services Agency of Japan announced its "plan to utilize provisional release actively for foreigners detained in custody facilities before deportation due to illegal stays and other reasons." "The agency decided to utilize provisional release actively for detainees with no infection symptoms, except for those who have committed serious crimes, as custody facilities often have enclosed and congested environments involving close contact, with high infection risks. In addition, the guidelines include isolating new detainees for around two weeks and limiting visits to detainees to consular officers and lawyers."
type_sub_cat: Prison population reduced (e.g. early release of prisoners)

description: On May 4, 2020, the Japan Sumo Association "has canceled the summer grand tournament in Tokyo due to the coronavirus pandemic." description: On May 4, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the "Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control" (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 4, 2020). In order to implement "2) Restrictions on holding events" it was decided that "All designated prefectures will make requests not to hold events where clusters could emerge or have gatherings under 3Cs circumstances, especially in cases of nation-wide or large events and gatherings."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 4 2020 the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariatissued a document titled “Regarding the Maintenance and Relaxation, etc of State of Emergency Measures”. With regards to (2) Designated prefectures other than the Prefectures under Special Caution as part of 2) restrictions on holding events it was decided that events, whether or not they are comparatively small (50 participants at most), need to meet the following conditions in order to be held: 1. The 3Cs should not occur in principle (2m distance between people where possible) 2. Singing, shouting and conversation in close quarters should not occur in principle. 3. If necessary, that appropriate infection prevention countermeasures (including use of masks, ventilation of indoor spaces, the installation of sanitiser equipmentand entry restrictions) are implemented.

enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (2) prefectures not subject to emergency measures as part of 2) Restrictions on holding events it was decided that events can be held under the assumption that appropriate infection prevention countermeasures are taken (use of masks, use of sanitiser, avoiding crowding in waiting areas, etc). The criterion for events also include:  Outdoor events are limited to under 200 people and sufficient space must be kept between people (2 meters where possible).
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 14, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 14, 2020). In order to regulate ‘6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures’ it was decided that ‘i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. One such sustainable measure was given as ‘Have organizers of nationwide, large-scale events (larger than a certain scale) demonstrate caution by cancelling or postponing them.’
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On May 14 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses Accompanying Changes in Areas Where Emergency Measures Should be Implemented”. With regards to (2) prefectures not subject to emergency measures as part of 2) Restrictions on holding events it was decided that prefectures will inform event organisers to create a register of attendees’ names and addresses and that a contact tracing app for smartphones that is being considered for introduction will contribute to infection prevention.

description: On May 14, 2020, the Okinawa Zento Eisa Matsuri executive committee announces that they will cancel the "65th Okinawa Zento Eisa Matsuri (hosted by the executive committee: Okinawa City, Ryukyu Shimpo Co. Ltd., Okinawa Television, the Okinawa Tourism and Industry Promotion Association, and the Okinawa City Youth Council)". This event features Eisa performances and was originally scheduled for September 11-13 in Okinawa City Stadium.

description: On May 15, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Yamanashi (Japan) announced that "it would shut the route on its side to the top of the Japan's tallest mountain," Mount Fuji (Yoshida trail). "Usually, the Fujinomiya, Subashiri and Gotenba trails on the Shizuoka side and the Yoshida trail on the Yamanashi side open between July and September."

description: On May 18, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Shizuoka (Japan) announced that "it will close all three trails on Mount Fuji on the central Japan prefecture's side this summer, following the spread of the novel coronavirus."

description: On May 20, 2020, "the Japan High School Baseball Federation and The Asahi Shimbun, a sponsor of the tournament, decided on the cancellation" of the summer National High School Baseball Championship, which was scheduled to start on August 10, 2020, "because of the novel coronavirus pandemic. At the same time, the prefectural tournaments to determine the 49 competing teams in the summer championship were also scrapped."

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). The MHLW implements “2) Restrictions on holding events” and states that “All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will make requests not to hold events where clusters could emerge or have gatherings under 3Cs circumstances, especially in cases of nation-wide or large events and gatherings.”

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). In order to regulate “6) Measures in prefectures not subject to emergency measures” it was decided that “i) Sustainable measures are expected to be needed. Under the declaration of the state of emergency, easing and lifting, such as of requests for self-restraint, should be carried out carefully.” Prefectures not subject to emergency measures [thus excluding Hokkaido, Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa and Saitama] can “Have organizers of nationwide, large-scale events (larger than a certain scale) demonstrate caution by cancelling or postponing them.”
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: On May 21, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on May 21, 2020). Section 3 addresses "Pandemic Prevention" and in order to promote “1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)” it was decided that “ii) All designated prefectures [Hokkaido, Saitama, Chiba, Tokyo and Kanagawa] will discourage citizens from visiting eateries with hospitality services in downtown areas where clusters have emerged.”

description: On May 25 2020, Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Prefectural Response during the Transition”. With regards to (4) important notes regarding preventing the spread of infections as part of 3) restrictions on holding events, it was decided that prefectures that meet half the number of new reports necessary for the re-imposition of a state of emergency, and those where there have been coronavirus clusters at events will be urged to co-ordinate with the national government to demand the suspension or remote hosting of events

description: On May 25 2020, Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Prefectural Response during the Transition”. With regards to (3) the response towards events like festivals as part of 3) restrictions on holding events it was decided that events where movement of people from around the country is not expected and where the number of participants is roughly known will be urged to take infection prevention measures. These measures include avoidance of the 3Cs, use of masks and self-restraint in attendance on the part of people experiencing symptoms of a cold or fever.

description: Until May 31st, for the types of facilities that have experienced cluster outbreaks, Kyoto Prefecture asked people to cooperate in the restriction of their usage.

In order to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus in Sendai City, it was decided to cancel or postpone events that gather a large number of people indoors, events that provide meals, etc. In response to the change in the handling policy, we will gradually relax the event holding restrictions.
However, in principle, we will continue to suspend or postpone large-scale events that involve the movement of people across the country and wide-area events and events for which the risk of infection cannot be fully addressed.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description:
In order to prevent the spread of the new coronavirus in Sendai City, it was decided to cancel or postpone events that gather a large number of people indoors, events that provide meals, etc. In response to the change in the handling policy, we will gradually relax the event holding restrictions.
However, in principle, we will continue to suspend or postpone large-scale events that involve the movement of people across the country and wide-area events and events for which the risk of infection cannot be fully addressed.

description:
This year’s memorial events for the Great East Japan Earthquake have been canceled one after another due to the spread of the COVID-19.
Even in Iwate, the only prefecture in the country that has so far had no cases of infection, most events around the Golden Week holidays in May were canceled. Organizers are now worried that the pandemic may have a lasting impact on holding disaster-related events next year, when it observes the 10th anniversary of the deadly March 11 quake and tsunami, as operations of nonprofit organizations supporting victims are having trouble continuing their activities.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: From June 1 to 18, Fukuoka Prefecture has requested residents, except in Kitakyushu City, to "carefully consider holding" entertainment festivals where it is difficult to manage the number of participants.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description: On 06-01-20, the Hiroshima Peace Memorial in Japan is set to reopen to the public, though at a limited number of visitors, after it was closed on February 1 due to the coronavirus pandemic.

description:
Fukuoka Prefecture announced that except in Kitakyushu City, outdoor events of less than 200 people can be held from June 1
until June 18. Sufficient social distancing of 2 metres should occur as much as possible.

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced that entertainment events such as sports which requires participants to travel nationwide cannot be held from June 1 to 18.

description:
Five public beaches in Ishinomaki, Miyagi Prefecture, including two which had planned to resume operation for the first time in a decade since they were swept away by the March 2011 earthquake-triggered tsunami, will not open this summer to help prevent the spread of coronavirus.
The city office plans to put up signs asking visitors to refrain from using the beaches.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of a recreational or commercial event

description: After being closed from April 12 until June 15 due to the coronavirus pandemic, the Oshimenawa Creative Museum in Shimane (Japan) will be reopened on June 16.

description: On May 25 2020, Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Prefectural Response during the Transition”. With regards to the (1) incremental relaxation of 3) restrictions on holding events, it was stated that between June 19 and July 9 indoor and outdoor events will be limited to under 1000 people. Indoor events will be limited to within half the venue’s capacity. Outdoor events will be urged to ensure enough space between people (2 meters where possible).

description: On June 19, the Hiroshima Research Institute in Japan reopened based on Hiroshima's coping policy to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection.

description: On June 19, 2020, the Japan Sport Association, the Japanese Para-Sports Association, the Kagoshima prefectural government and the Japan Sports Agency "decided to put off the 75th National Sports Festival, originally slated for October in Kagoshima Prefecture, marking the first postponement of the annual event that began in 1946. A similar decision was made for the 20th annual national para-sports festival, originally set to start also in the southwestern prefecture following the National Sports Festival." "The two events usually bring together about 800,000 people, including spectators, in total."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On June 24, the Hiroshima prefecture (Japan) released the following conditions of holding an event, which will remain in effect until July 9:

"If it is indoors, the number of participants should be less than 1,000 and less than half of the capacity.
If it is outdoors, 1,000 people or less and a sufficient distance between people (2m as much as possible)
Regarding the holding of large-scale events nationwide, we ask the organizer to take careful measures to cancel or postpone it if the risk assessment cannot be completed."

With regards to (2) points of note concerning holding events as part of 2) restrictions on holding events it was decided that each prefecture will call for event organisers’ attention to the following point: before holding the event, participants should be urged to install the contact tracing app. Moreover, for infection prevention purposes participants’ contact addresses, etc should be firmly grasped.

description: On 2020-07-08, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses After July 10”. With regards to (1) criteria for holding events as part of 2)restrictions on holding events it was decided that under the assumption that the appropriate infection prevention measures are being taken, outdoor events can be held with a restriction of under 5000 participants, as well as keeping an appropriate distance between people (2 meters where possible)
