description: On 2020-07-08, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses After July 10”. With regards to (2) points of note concerning holding events as part of 2) restrictions on holding events it was decided that, in order to guarantee the effectiveness of advance co-ordination between prefectures and event organisers, each prefecture will request the facility managers of facilities which are expected to be used for events necessitating cross-national movement or of facilities where participants are likely to exceed 1000 persons to speak to the prefecture in advance regarding the requirements for holding the event.

description: On 2020-07-08, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses After July 10”. With regards to (2) points of note concerning holding events as part of 2) restrictions on holding events it was decided that each prefecture will call for event organisers’ attention to the following point: implement temperature measurement when participants are entering and ask for persons showing symptoms of a fever, etc not to participate. In these cases, refunds, etc should be provided.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 2020-07-08, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses After July 10”. With regards to (2) points of note concerning holding events as part of 2) restrictions on holding events it was decided that each prefecture will call for event participants’ attention regarding the following point: people experiencing symptoms of a fever should not participate.

description: On May 25 2020, Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Prefectural Response during the Transition”. With regards to the (1) incremental relaxation of3) restrictions on holding events, it was stated that between July 10 and July 31, indoor and outdoor events will be limited to under 5000 people. Indoor events will be limited to within half the venue’s capacity. Outdoor events will be urged to ensure enough space between people (2 meters where possible). Where spectators and participants are clearly separated, the above numerical restrictions only apply to event participants.

description: On 2020-07-08, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses After July 10”. With regards to (2) points of note concerning holding events as part of 2) restrictions on holding events it was decided that each prefecture will call for event participants’ attention regarding the following point: while participating, a mask should be worn except where measures against heatstroke, etc are necessary. Moreover, diligent hand-washing and other conduct based on the “New Lifestyle” should be thoroughly carried out.

description: On 2020-07-08, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses After July 10”. With regards to (1) criteria for holding events as part of 2) restrictions on holding events it was decided that under the assumption that the appropriate infection prevention measures are being taken, indoor events can be held with a restriction of under 5000 participants, as well as within half of the venue’s maximum capacity.

description: On 2020-07-08, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses After July 10”. description: On the 13 July 2020, the Osaka prefectural government asked its residents not to visit nightlife entertainment establishments with poor measures against the new coronavirus. This request will be effective until 31 July 2020.

On July 14, 2020, Miyakojima (Okinawa, Japan) announced the cancellation of the annual gathering to show respect for the aged (敬老会, keirōkai in Japanese), scheduled for September 2020, in order to reduce the risk of infection.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description:
On July 17, the governor of the Yamaguchi Prefecture issued a declaration setting guidelines for mass gatherings. 

"The scale is less than 5,000 people both indoors and outdoors. When indoors, the number of participants is less than half of the capacity, and when outdoors, there is a sufficient distance between people. please. Also, if you plan to hold an event that involves the movement of people nationwide or an event that involves more than 1,000 participants, please consult the prefecture in advance."
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On July 26, 2020, the Okinawa Bullfighting Association (Uruma City, Okinawa, Japan) announced the decision "to cancel the '11th All-Okinawa Summer Bullfighting Festival' set to take place at the Ishikawa Dome in Uruma in August."
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: On July 28 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Comprehensive efforts to prevent the outbreak of clusters at restaurants, etc”. As part of (1) promoting a change in behaviour suitable for the “New Everyday” within 2) Efforts to encourage restaurant users adopt behaviour to protect themselves it was decided that people will be encouraged to exercise self-restraint in activity where speaking in a loud voice would occur (e.g. karaoke, speaking loudly at a restaurant, spectating a sports event).
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
type_text: Policy encouraging people to avoid a variety of settings and activities where speaking loudly (or singing, shouting, etc) would likely occur. Consequently, they are encouraged to avoid environments like concerts, large sports events, karaoke boxes, etc
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced on July 30 for residents to "refrain from dining and going out for drinks in large groups".

description: On 2020-07-23, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Restrictions on Holding Events After August 1”. As part of 3) Points of note regarding holding events like festivals, etc it was decided that prefectures will continue to urge events where cross-national movement or movement over a wide area is expected and those where it is difficult for the number of participants to be grasped to make careful considerations, including for event suspension

As part of 1) Criteria for holding events it was stated that restrictions on holding events would be as follows until the end of August: indoor events will be limited to under 5000 people. Indoor events will be limited to within 50% of the venue’s capacity.

enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On July 31, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with its own declaration of a state of emergency, asked to consider cancelling, postponing or reducing the scale of events and to take sufficient measures against infection when holding events from August 1, 2020 until August 15, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On 2020-07-23, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Restrictions on Holding Events After August 1”. As part of 3) Points of note regarding holding events like festivals, etc it was decided that prefectures will continue to urge event organisers to encourage event participants to install the contact tracing apps being provided by the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare and each region. Prefectures will also continue to encourage event organisers to thoroughly grasp the contact addresses of participants for infection prevention purposes.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 2020-07-23, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Restrictions on Holding Events After August 1”. Outdoor events will ensure sufficient space between people (2 meters where possible).
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On 2020-07-23, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Restrictions on Holding Events After August 1”. As part of 3) Points of note regarding holding events like festivals, etc it was decided that prefectures will continue to call for appropriate infection prevention measures (including calling for people experiencing symptoms of fever or a cold to refrain from participating, encouraging the use of masks, the use of hand sanitiser and ensuring a minimum of 1 meter space between people)
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan), jointly with the extension of its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, asked to consider holding events online, reducing their scale, and cancel events, when sufficient measures against infection cannot be taken, until August 29, 2020.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On August 4, 2020, the Imperial Household Agency (Japan) announced that the "imperial garden party planned for the fall has been canceled to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus amid growing concern over a resurgence of infections." "Around 2,000 guests usually attend the parties at the Akasaka Imperial Gardens in Tokyo, where the emperor and empress greet and converse with those who have made notable constructions to the worlds of culture, sports and science."
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 5, 2020, the city of Itoman announces the cancellation of the annual gathering to show respect for the aged which was scheduled for October.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: On August 6, the Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) celebrated the 75th anniversary of the nuclear assault at the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park. The coronavirus forced them to curtail the events, moving conferences on nuclear disarmament online, canceling or postponing related meetings and reducing the number of attendees to around 800, one-tenth of the turnout during a normal year.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On August 6, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "urged citizens [...] to take thorough measures to prevent new coronavirus infection during the "Bon" holiday period in mid-August." Abe asked ""people to make sure to take basic infection prevention measures when visiting parents' homes" during the Bon period." "Regarding trips to hometowns, Abe also called on people to refrain from events at high risks of infection, such as dining in a large group, and take extra care to protect elderly people from the virus."
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)

description: On August 6, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Aichi (Japan), jointly with its own declaration of a state of emergency, called "on the public to not have meals or parties in a group of five or more."
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)

description: On 05-29-20, the Hiroshima Municipal Government (Japan) announced that it will downsize this year’s peace memorial ceremony for the atomic bombing due to the coronavirus outbreak. Rather than being open to general participants, only atomic bomb survivors and relatives of the victims will be invited.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions

description: On August 12, 2020, Miyakojima (Okinawa, Japan) announced the cancellation of the annual summer children's ecotour, scheduled for August 21, 2020, in order to reduce the risk of infection.

description: On August 13, 2020, the Prefectural Government of Okinawa (Japan) extended its declaration of a state of emergency until August 29, 2020, and asked to reduce gatherings to a small number of people and, when gathering, to take preventive infection measures, such as not sitting face-to-face.
type_sub_cat: Events at private residencies restricted (e.g. parties held at home)

description: On August 24 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding restrictions on holding events after September 1”. description: On August 24 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events after September 1”. As part of 2) Points of note regarding holding events it was decided that,regarding events necessitating movement across the country and events which are likely to exceed 1000 people, prefectures will respond by engaging in advance discussions with these events’ organisers.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces that between September 1 and 30, 2020,  the maximum number of participants for indoor events will continue to be 5,000 and be up to half of the admission capacity.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces on August 25, 2020 that restrictions on outdoor events will be extended until September 30, 2020. 5,000 participants or less are allowed to attend.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: From September 1 to 30, 2020, for events where it is expected people will move nationwide or over a wide area, or events for which it is difficult to grasp the number of participants, Fukuoka Prefecture recommends organizers to consider cancellation.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announces that organizers should continue to consult the government on events requiring nationwide movement with more than 1,000 participants.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On August 20, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) announced that the planned exhibition "600th Anniversary Memorial-Sesshu and Kano School" (9/15-10/18), "Komura Yukitai Style" (10/30-1/3), and related projects scheduled to be held by the end of the year will be postponed due to the spread of the new coronavirus nationwide.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, on Sep. 14, 2020, the Hokkaido government announces restrictions on events and areas with loud cheering and shouting and so on (Classical Music Concert, Theatre, dance, traditional arts, etc., Performing arts, performances, and ceremonies, Exhibition, etc.). Seats have to be reduced by 50% with at least 1 free seat, groups are allowed up until 5 persons, from Sep. 19th until the end of Nov. 2020.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (1) criteria for holding events within 1) restrictions on holding events it was decided that regarding events where it is assumed that shouting and loud talking will not occur, a 100% occupancy rate will be permitted if all the below conditions are met: There has not been shouting, cheering or singing by participants at any similar event up until now which the performer has previously been part of. If event organisers do not provide sufficient explanation based on the past outcomes of similar events, they will be dealt with as events where it is hypothesised that shouting and cheering will occur.Based on the actual results of previously held events, individual participants will be asked to thoroughly carry out infection prevention measures, including the wearing of masks.Infection prevention measures for each industry as formulated in infection prevention guidelines, such as ensuring sufficient space between audience members and shouting/signing performers, are implemented.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (2) advance conversation with prefectures within 2) points of note regarding holding events it was decided that prefectures should call for event participants’ and organisers’ attention regarding infection prevention measures and engage in advance discussions with event organisers where the event necessitates cross-national movement or is likely to surpass 1000 participants.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (1) criteria for holding events within 1) restrictions on holding events it was decided that where shouting and cheering is expected but where participants’ location is fixed and their movement can be controlled, a vacant seat will be kept between each group (no more than 5 people) or individual.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (1) criteria for holding events within 1) restrictions on holding events it was decided that where shouting and cheering is expected and participants can freely move but their conduct in the area and when entering/exiting the venue can be controlled, the number of participants will be limited to 50% of the venue’s capacity when there is one. Where there is no defined capacity, it is necessary for sufficient space (1 meter) to be kept between people.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (2) regional events and national or outdoor festivals within 1) restrictions on holding events it was decided that each prefecture will take the following response: Regarding events on a national scale or where it is difficult to grasp the number of participants, prefectures will continue to urge careful consideration from event organisers, including for event suspension. If the event is held, organisers will be urged to ensure enough space between people (1 meter). If this is difficult, careful judgement will be made regarding holding the event.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (1) a call for attention regarding infection prevention measures based on evidence within 2) Points of note regarding holding events it was stated that prefectures are requested to co-ordinate with event organisers to carry out appropriate risk assessments based on the regional infection situation, nature of the event and impact on the regional medical system.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (2) regional events and national or outdoor festivals within 1) restrictions on holding events it was decided that each prefecture will take the following response: Regarding events where cross-national movement is not expected and where the number of participants can roughly be grasped, event organisers will be urged to adopt the use of contact tracing apps developed and adopted by the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (COCOA) and each region. They will also be urged to grasp the contact addresses of event participants.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (1) a call for attention regarding infection prevention measures based on evidence within 2) Points of note regarding holding events it was stated that prefectures will urge event organisers to ensure sufficient ventilation in indoor environments, implement policies in response to the risk of contact and droplet infection, implement policies to prevent infected persons from attending and mechanisms to identify people who might be affected when an infection occurs.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (1) criteria for holding events within 1) restrictions on holding events it was decided that where a venue has an established capacity and where the requirements for relaxing restrictions on holding events are secured, the upper limit for participants will be set at the higher number between either 5000 people or 50% of the venue’s capacity.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (1) criteria for holding events within 1) restrictions on holding events it was decided that where a venue has an established capacity but where requirements for relaxing restrictions on holding events are not secured, the upper limit for participants will be set at 5000 people.
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On September 11 2020, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued “Regarding restrictions on holding events until the end of November”. As part of (2) regional events and national or outdoor festivals within 1) restrictions on holding events it was decided that each prefecture will take the following response: Regarding events where cross-national movement is not expected and where the number of participants can roughly be grasped, event organisers will continue to be called upon to implement appropriate infection prevention measures (maintaining 1 meter space between people, avoiding the 3Cs, use of masks, use of hand sanitiser, etc).
type_sub_cat: Other mass gatherings not specified above restricted
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description:
On May 22, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) announced that the annual Yamaguchi Kenjinkai World Grand Meeting, originally scheduled for autumn 2020, has been postponed after after careful consideration of the effects of COVID-19.

"It is held to gather overseas Kenjinkais in one area to strengthen bonds with Yamaguchi Prefecture and promote a network with Yamaguchi and its Kenjinkais across the world. Since the first Grand Meeting held in Yamaguchi City in 2004, there have been four Grand Meetings organized."
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On August 31, the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan) announced that the Cycle Prefecture Yamaguchi Symbol Event All Yamaguchi Ride Festa 2020 Regarding "Yamaguchi Tokigagamine International Downhill" was cancelled to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of a recreational or commercial event

description: On December 9, 2020, it was announced that the Imperial Household Agency (Japan) "canceled celebratory events typically held to mark" the birthday of Empress Masako, who turned 57 on December 9, "due to the novel coronavirus pandemic."
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Fukuoka City announces that Coming-of-Age Day on January 11, 2021, which is a ceremony for new adults, will be split into two parts and livestreamed online to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The city further advises participants to install the COCOA tracking app on their phone before visiting the venue.
type_sub_cat: Annually recurring event allowed to occur with certain conditions

description: Fukuoka Prefecture announced on January 8 that residents who have symptoms such as coughing or fever after returning from Wuhan City should wear a mask.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: On February 14, 2020, at the Ninth Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked "the elderly or those with underlying diseases to pay attention to prevention, including by avoiding visiting sites where a lot of people may gather."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, on Feb. 28 Akita government announces: „At this point, we do not make a uniform request for self-restraint for meetings and events, but we ask that you reconsider the necessity of holding the meeting, including cancellation, postponement, and reduction in size.“
Japan, on Feb.28th the Aomori government asks residents for social distancing: avoiding places with much a lot of people, stay at home except for nessescary duties.
Japan, on Mar. 19 Yamagata government requests to refrain from visiting infected patients in the hospitals from March: "3 月から入院患者の方への面会を原則として禁止させていただいております。“

In March 2020, the Tottori Prefectural Government (Japan) introduced a “Tottori-type office system” to review the layout of office desks, such as securing the distance between employees and installing partitions between desks, for the following purposes. 

"This Tottori-type office system is one of the ways to live while preventing infectious diseases in the Tottori-type “new lifestyle”. With a little effort, you can expect to reduce the risk of infection. Please refer to it at your workplace."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description:
In March 2020, the Tottori Prefectural Government (Japan) introduced a “Tottori-type office system” to review the layout of office desks, such as securing the distance between employees and installing partitions between desks, for the following purposes. 

"This Tottori-type office system is one of the ways to live while preventing infectious diseases in the Tottori-type “new lifestyle”. With a little effort, you can expect to reduce the risk of infection. Please refer to it at your workplace."
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: Japan, on Mar. 6 Yamagata government requests residents to social distance themselves: „[R]efrain from gatherings or events where people from outside the prefecture are likely to be present.“
From March 6, Fukuoka Prefecture announced that residents who need to go to the hospital for a COVID-19 consultation should "wear a mask" and "avoid using public transport such as trains and buses".
From March 6, Fukuoka Prefecture announced that residents who need to go to the hospital for a COVID-19 consultation should "wear a mask" and "avoid using public transport such as trains and buses".
From March 6, Fukuoka Prefecture announced that residents who need to go to the hospital for a COVID-19 consultation should "wear a mask" and "avoid using public transport such as trains and buses".

Japan, on Mar. 23 Iwate government requests residents to self restrain: "I would like to reiterate to the residents of the prefecture that avoiding the three conditions of infection, which are sealing, crowding, and close contact".

In Tokyo, Japan on March 25, 2020, Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike asked Tokyo residents to "avoid visits to bars and restaurants, and put karaoke sessions on hold".  Furthermore, residents have been asked to "refrain from going out in the evenings, and to refrain from all unnecessary outings at the weekend.” This recommendation is effective until April 12, 2020.

In Tokyo, Japan on March 26, 2020, Tokyo Governor Yuriko Koike and the governors of neighboring Chiba, Saitama, Chiba, and Kanagawa prefectures held a joint teleconference, "urging their people to avoid leaving home for nonessential purposes, to prevent an explosive surge in COVID-19 infections."  The governors stressed avoiding crowds, poorly ventilated areas, and events in order to avoid a wide-spread lockdown.
Japan, on Mar. 27 Fukushima government asks residents to wear masks "[i]n the case that you have to go outside for essential reasons".

On March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (Revised on March 28, 2020). In order to guarantee (3) Pandemic prevention, it was agreed to “[p]resent appropriate measures to prevent clusters and reduce contacts, based on the local situations” and to “[c]all for cooperation in self-restraint in avoiding gatherings in closed spaces, crowded places, or close-contact settings. Pay particular attention to metropolitan areas.”
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: Japan, on Mar. 30 Iwate prefecture asks (especially young people) to refrain from participating in events and to work via telework if possible: „We call for the careful action of young people who find it difficult to detect infections, refrain from events, and cooperate with the implementation of telework.“

Japan, on Mar. 31 Fukushima government requests residents to refrain from going out and avoid crowded places when showing symptoms. Furthermore “Three Cs”－ “Closed spaces with poor ventilation”, “Crowded places with many people nearby”, and “Close-contact settings such as close-range conversations”should be avoided.
Japan, govenor of Wakayama asks residents for self restrain, especially to consider when to leave home.
Japan, on Apr. 1  Yamagata government requests young people to refrain from going out in the evenings, i.e. to visit drinking establshments and restaurants.

From April 2, 2020, the Ministry of Defense of Japan (MOD) "has started introducing a rotating work-shift system to ensure that its operations can continue without disruptions in the event someone within its structure becomes infected with the coronavirus." "The notification instructs all departments [...] to divide their staff members into several teams. The teams will be put to work in different times of the day or told to work at home every other day."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan "adopted a policy of having asymptomatic or mildly ill patients of the COVID-19 coronavirus disease stay at home, in hotels or certain other places, in areas where infections are rapidly spreading."
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government

description: Japan, on Apr. 03 Iwate government requests people to refrain from going out on weekends as wells as weekdays nights for the next two weeks: "„I would like you to be cautious about your activities, such as refraining from going out for "unnecessary urgency" on weekdays during the night and on weekends for the next two weeks.“

On April 6, 2020 "the Minami-Daito Novel Coronavirus Task Force (led by Mayor Kensho Nakada) held its third meeting at the village hall. With infections spreading domestically and internationally, [...] [t]he Task Force asks residents to prevent the spread of the disease by wearing masks, washing their hands, and avoiding the 3 C’s: closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On April 6, 2020 "the Minami-Daito Novel Coronavirus Task Force (led by Mayor Kensho Nakada) held its third meeting at the village hall. With infections spreading domestically and internationally, [...] [t]he Task Force asks residents to prevent the spread of the disease by wearing masks, washing their hands, and avoiding the 3 C’s: closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings."

Miyazato Satoru, village mayor of Zamami Island (Kerama Islands, Okinawa, Japan), encouraged residents to avoid "3C spaces" (closed spaces, crowded places, close-contact settings) through a notice published on April 7, 2020.

On April 7, 2020, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare of Japan (MHLW) issued the “Basic Policies for Novel Coronavirus Control” (published on March 28, 2020, revised on April 7, 2020). Accordingly, the Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare will, with the aim of preventing nosocomial infection in medical institutions and facilities for the elderly, “[t]ake every possible precaution to prevent workers from being a source of infection by thoroughly avoiding the place where "3Cs" overlap at the same time, by making sure for workers to wear masks, wash and disinfect hands, disinfect regularly shared facilities, maintain a certain distance each other when eating and drinking, keep their daily health tracks and stay home if their physical condition is not perfect.”
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: From April 7, 2020, the government of Japan has asked the seven prefectures placed under a state of emergency (Tokyo, Chiba, Saitama, Kanagawa, Hyogo, Osaka, and Fukuoka) "to reduce the amount of physical contact among people by 80%". Prime Minister Abe has encouraged the population to "make efforts and reduce opportunities for person-to-person contact by a minimum of 70 percent, or ideally 80 percent" during the press conference regarding the Declaration of a State of Emergency on April 7, 2020.
Japan, Wakayama government requests social distancing and self-quarantine: request to „refrain from visiting any place other than your workplace or medical institution“ until May6th.
Japan, Govenor of Gifu requests residents to follow the measure of social distancing: "When possible, stay 2 meters apart from other people."

Japan, on Apr. 10 Yamagata government requests residents to social distance themselves: „Even within the prefecture, refrain from unnecessary activities and outing. Please be careful for your own sake and for the sake of those around you.“

Japan, Govenor of Gifu requests residents to follow the measure of social distancing: "When possible, stay 2 meters apart from other people." Gifu prefecture decides to extend the end of social distancing from May 6 to an undefined day.
Japan, based on the central government’s decision, on Apr. 11 Fukushima govenor asks residents of Fukushima "to refrain from going to nightclubs, hostess bars and the like in busy downtown areas".
Japan, on Apr. 12 Iwate government requests to refrain from going out to restaurants, and using other service facilities in the downtown area.

From April 13 until May 6, Hiroshima Prefecture (Japan) declares itself to be in a state of warning for the spread of COVID-19, establishing social distancing protocols for Hiroshima residents and business owners.

description:
Japan, Yamato City, Kanagawa Prefecture, has enacted and enforced the "Omoiyari Mask Wearing Ordinance" on Apr.16.
The ordinance requires citizens to be considerate and wear masks to prevent infection:
„神奈川県大和市は16日、新型コロナウイルスの感染拡大を防ぐため、マスクの着用を呼びかける「おもいやりマスク着用条例」を制定、施行した。罰則規定はない。“
type_text: The municipal government requests to wear masks outside.
target_geog_level: One or more geographical or administrative units within one or more countries

description: Japan, on Apr. 17 Miyagi government requests "citizens to refrain from non-essential outings", "[e]xcluding hospital visits, grocery/pharmaceutical/daily essential purchases, necessary commutes to work, outdoor exercise, and other indispensable activities for daily living" from Apr. 17 until May 6. "In particular, the government strongly requests refraining from entering dining establishments in busy areas, regardless of age."

Starting from April 17, 2020, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Japan (MOFA) stated: "Starting from today, we will livestream this press conference on the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official Twitter account. In addition to livestreaming on MOFA’s Japanese language account, we will also livestream the press conference with simultaneous interpretation on our English account. We will also be livestreaming my regular press conference in English too."
enforcer: National Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: Japan, in Aomori prefecture  "all citizens of the prefecture are requested to refrain from going out when they are not necessary or urgent“ and to "refrain from going out to restaurants, etc. that are accompanied by entertainment in the downtown area." by Aomori government from Apr.17 until May6.

On April 23, 2020, the Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare, with the Prime Minister’s Office of Japan and the Government of Japan Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control within the Cabinet Secretariat published a poster titled “This Golden Week, let’s avoid going out!” This poster encourages social distancing and advises people in Japan to go shopping during quiet periods and within one’s neighbourhood, visit parks when they are quiet and go jogging when there are no crowds.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: Japan, Miyagi government requests residents to limit the number of people going grocery shopping or visiting parks together to avoid congestion from Apr. 24 until May 6.

Japan, on Apr. 23 Tokyo government requests residents „to limit the frequency of grocery shopping to every three days as part of steps to prevent supermarkets becoming too crowded“ from Apr. 25 until May 6.

As announced on April 27 by the Yamaguchi Prefecture (Japan), public transport operators are taking the following preventive measures against infectious diseases.

"As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, we are encouraging airport staff to wear masks and install disinfectant solutions at airport entrances to encourage airport users to disinfect their hands.
In addition, each airline also implements measures such as wearing masks and gloves for flight attendants and ground personnel, disinfecting cabins in the cabin, and circulating air.

As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, bus crews wear masks to operate and guide passengers. In addition, we are implementing disinfection and ventilation inside the vehicle, as well as restrictions on the use of buses in the front row in order to keep the distance between the driver and the driver.

As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, we are implementing measures such as employee wearing masks and installing disinfectant.

As a preventive measure against infectious diseases, we are implementing measures such as wearing masks for employees and arousing and disinfecting trains."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

In order to promote "1) Refraining from leaving home (except for going to workplaces, as mentioned later)" it was decided that "ii) All designated prefectures will carefully avoid the "3Cs" while also taking basic measures to prevent infection, such as handwashing and maintaining social distancing between people."

description: On May 7, 2020, the Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi, in charge for Economic Revitalization, "asked prefectures on the special alert to continue to keep measures in place. The government is to analyze in detail the effects of calls by central and local governments to refrain from nonessential outings and hometown visits during the spring break."

On May 9, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on residents of 13 prefectures where special alert for the novel coronavirus is requested to continue efforts to reduce interpersonal contact by 80 pct. The government is concerned about the possibility of citizens in the 13 prefectures - Tokyo, Chiba, Kanagawa, Saitama, Osaka, Hyogo, Fukuoka, Hokkaido, Ibaraki, Ishikawa, Gifu, Aichi and Kyoto - relaxing their social distancing efforts."

description:
Starting from May 14, 2020, Sendai city gave rules to customers in restaurants. 
• The tables should be separated by partitions to prevent splash infection, or side-by-side with a space of at least 2m (at least 1m).
Arrange the layout so that you can sit in, and open an appropriate space so that the counter seats do not stick together.
• Avoid direct layout, or devise a partition (such as acrylic plate) on the table.
• If you want to meet face-to-face with a small number of family members and caregivers, such as the elderly, infants and people with disabilities, this may be possible, but with other groups
Avoid sharing seats.
• To ensure safety between groups, keep at least 2m (at least 1m) away from other groups and keep conversations modest.
And consider recommending listening to BGM.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On May 16, 2020, the Government of Japan "called on people to stay alert against the new coronavirus." The Minister of State for Economic and Fiscal Policy of Japan Nishimura Yasutoshi stated that "carelessness can lead to a new wave of the outbreak, urging people not to relax efforts to contain the virus," calling on "residents of the 39 prefectures to continue containment efforts while resuming economic activities gradually. For residents of the eight prefectures where the state of emergency is still in place, Nishimura underlined the need for continued efforts to reduce contact by 80 pct."

On May 17, 2020, the Government of Japan "called for continued voluntary restrictions by residents of the eight prefectures where its coronavirus state of emergency remains in effect" (Hokkaido, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Saitama, Chiba, Osaka, Kyoto and Hyogo). "Economic and fiscal policy minister Yasutoshi Nishimura called for these residents' continued cooperation to ensure that the state of emergency is lifted within this month. "A second wave of infections could come. People should continue voluntary restrictions without becoming relaxed about them," Nishimura said."

description: From June 1, 2020, Japan's carrier All Nippon Airways "will make it mandatory for passengers to wear a mask aboard planes and at the airport." "[E]veryone will be required to wear a mask at all times on planes and at the airport, including at security checkpoints and boarding gates. The airline says it may deny boarding to people not wearing a mask or showing symptoms of illness, including fever. Exceptions will be made for small children and certain particular cases."

On 2020-07-08, the Office for Novel Coronavirus Disease Control of Japan’s Cabinet Secretariat issued a document titled “Regarding Prefectural Responses After July 10”. With regards to 1) self-restraint in going out, it was decided that each prefecture should encourage people, when they do go out, to behave based on the “New Lifestyle”, such as via the wearing of masks and use of hand sanitiser. Prefectures should also urge people to refrain from going out to facilities which are not thoroughly implementing infection prevention measures.

On July 22, 2020, at the 41th Meeting of the Novel Coronavirus Response Headquarters, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe asked "people to make every effort to avoid the three Cs (closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings), refrain from activities that involve raising their voices, and take full preventive measures such as wearing face masks, hand-washing, sanitization, and ventilation."
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere

description: From July 30, 2020, Fukuoka Prefecture extends the request for residents to use masks and practise "physical distancing" when going out.

description: On 2020-08-05, Japan’s Subcommittee on Novel Coronavirus Infection Countermeasures published “Regarding returning home for the Bon holidays”. As part of this document, it was requested that people thoroughly follow basic infection prevention measures (wearing masks, use of hand sanitiser, avoiding shouting and sufficient ventilation) as well as avoiding the 3Cs to the best of one’s ability.
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,New (COVID-19 specific) Task Force

description: On August 6, 2020, the Prime Minister of Japan Shinzo Abe "urged citizens [...] to take thorough measures to prevent new coronavirus infection during the "Bon" holiday period in mid-August." Abe asked ""people to make sure to take basic infection prevention measures when visiting parents' homes" during the Bon period [...] such measures as avoiding the three Cs of closed, crowded and close contact settings and not speaking loudly."
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: On August 7, the governor of the Shimane Prefecture (Japan) urged citizens to refrain from “dining in large groups of people accompanied with alcohol consumption,”which has a high risk of infection.

As a part of measures by Yellow Alert in Osaka prefecture, Osaka prefecture requested citizens, especially elderly people and family members who come into contact with the elderly people on a daily basis, to refrain from an environment with a high risk of infection and have any symptoms. This measure has planned to implement from October 10 to November 15th.

On November 4, 2020, the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism of Japan (MLIT) "allowed taxi drivers in Tokyo to refuse passengers who are not wearing face masks without a valid reason." ""The provision does not endorse an across-the-board refusal of people who are not wearing face masks," a transport ministry official said, adding that if their customers are maskless, taxi drivers should check whether they have health or other unavoidable reasons."
